title: hatton garden basil caught camera chatting leader cops
story: Jurors heard how Michael Seed, , allegedly met John “Kenny” Collins in public parks on two occasions soon after the robbery.Just over , items of jewellery, gold, watches and bundles of valuable stones were later found in Seed’s bedroom following his arrest in March last year, it was alleged.Woolwich Crown Court was also told that Seed had consistently similar “reliable characteristics” to Basil’s “particular habitual gait” seen on CCTV during the Easter  heist.Prosecutor Philip Evans, QC, said a chiropodist and podiatrist reviewed police surveillance footage of Seed and compared it with CCTV of Basil from the record-breaking safety deposit box centre raid.Mr Evans added: “The expert noted the right leg movement and position of the foot and lower limb have a similar appearance at ious stages of the gait cycle in both sets of footage…“It is the expert’s opinion that there is strong evidence to support the proposition that Seed is Basil.”Mr Evans also said  items found at Seeds home were positively identied by safety deposit box owners as theirs – with  more described as being “consistent” to valuables stolen from them.Those items were valued overall at £,. by Wilsons Auctioneers, said Mr Evans.Jurors heard that Basil played a key role in the £million heist, and was one of two bandits to tunnel through a small hole into the vault.CCTV cameras captured Basil wearing a blue boiler suit, white gloves and carrying a black bin bag on his shoulder to shield his face from cameras, the court heard.He was disguised with a wig, face mask and earphones as he broke in through the main door of - Hatton Garden before letting accomplices in through a side fire exit during the raid carried out over two nights.Basil played the main role in disabling the alarm system and fellow gang members paid tribute to his skills during a covert police recording, the court heard.Mr Evans said a large number of books on electronics and surveillance were found along with covert audio and vibration recording devices during the search of Seed’s home in Islington, North London.Jurors also heard DNA profiles on a glove discovered at the scene of a similar £million raid at Mayfair jewellers Chatila in  allegedly links Seed to the raid with convicted Hatton Garden thieves Daniel Jones and Terry Perkins.Jones pleaded guilty to the break-in at the jewellers while Perkins died while awaiting trial, the court heard.Seed denies two charges of conspiracy to commit burglary and one charge of conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property.The trial continues." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   .main_image.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E"  How the Hatton Garden heist was executed

title: couple make gofundme page pay wedding
story: Cash-strapped Natalie Borg and Richard McMurray have so far raised £ for their big day on April .The former belly dancer and her fiance have been working overtime and even flogged their belongings to pay for everything.But with only three months to go they are falling short of their final bills and launched the appeal two weeks ago.Posting on GoFundMe, the couple said: We’ve done the math and are still short ofto cover our outgoings for our planned wedding on Saturday th April .Despite throwing all our wages at the wedding costs, selling our belongings and taking as many extra shts at work as are available we are still falling short of our final bills.As we can’t put off the wedding for another few months -we are asking in lieu of any wedding gtsyou are able to please contribute anything to our costs for the day that would be amazing.They added: Final payments we are are still trying to cover are mainly for the venue, photographer, cake and dress alterations.We have no honeymoon budget and not worrying about this just want to be able to cover our bills for the day so it can go ahead.Thank you you in advance to anyone able to help.The pair, who got engaged in January last year, have raised £ towards their target in two weeks.And theyve already managed to pay for their wedding rings, registry and favours - as well as cash towards the venue, dress alterations, hair and makeup.To help them afford their big day, visit their fundraising page here.

title: rolf harris walks primary school waves confronted teacher
story: The shamed former TV star, , was told to leave by the head teacher of the school in Maidenhead, Berks.A witness, who took pictures of Harris stalking the grounds, told the Mirror: “I couldn’t believe what I was seeing.”The disgraced entertainer - who served three years in prison for a string of historical sex offences - shook hands with the head teacher before he was ordered off the site, the paper says.Richard Jarrett, head of Oldfield Primary School, insisted Harris had no access to the pupils and informed the police.But parents are outraged that he was able to wave and smile at their children.Mr Jarrett said: “We’ve got a wood sculptor working close to the road at the moment and Rolf Harris lives near to the school.He must have seen him [the sculptor] and come into the school area.He had no access to the children whatsoever.Harris explained that he was there to pick up some wood from the sculptor - but Mr Jarrett told him: You need to go.Askedhe was concerned about the paedo waving at children, the teacher replied: I was not there at the time to stop him waving at the children.”Shamed Animal Hospital star Harris was sentenced in June  to five years nine months in prison for a dozen indecent assaults against four teenage girls between  and .He was released on license after three years in May  - with his sentence running out in March next year.Harris is thought to have been placed on the Sex Offenders Register - but it is not clearhe will have breached this by entering the school grounds.Aussie Rolf was photographed outside the school at about noon on Tuesday wearing a red jacket similar to the one he wore in his infamous mugshot.The passer-by who took the snaps said: I could not believe what I was seeing. A convicted paedophile should not be in the grounds of a primary school.“He was waving at the children through the window. I think they were on lunch or maybe in class.They were waving back at him and clearly had no idea who he was.”And a furious mum of two said: “For him to just be able to freely walk in is not a good thing.If you’re a paedophile you can’t be going near a school. I’m disgusted.”The Ministry of Justice said: “When sex offenders are released they are subject to strict licence conditions and are liable to be ed to custody for breaching them.We are looking into these reports and will take appropriate action.”A police spokesman said: “Thames Valley Police was called to Oldfield Primary School at around .pm today.“A report was made that a man was on the site of the school.An officer attended the scene but no offence was committed. No arrests were made.”Harris was not at home to comment, according to the Mirror.

title: margaret thatcher statue lincolnshire
story: Councillors in Grantham, Lincs, backed plans for the £, monument to the ex-PM, which was originally intended for Parliament Square in Westminster.It will stand on a ft granite plinth to deter a “motivated far-left movement who may be committed to public activism”.Fears over vandalism led one councillor to suggest it would be better placed “in the middle of a pond”.Members dismissed objections on grounds of cost and Mrs Thatcher’s “isive policies”.Westminster Council rejected the statue last year over concerns it would attract “vandalism and civil disorder”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: spanish patrol boat stand off navy gibraltar
story: The episode had echoes of historic maritime victories against the Spanish by Admiral Lord Nelson at Trafalgar in  and Sir Francis Drake against the Armada in .In yesterday’s incident tiny HMS Sabre was involved in manoeuvres with a Royal Navy RHIB, when the Spanish vessel - the Tornado - blatantly sailed into the training drill yesterday morning where it stayed for two hours.As it passed into territorial waters the Spanish national anthem could be heard over Channel , a maritime communications frequency but it was not clear where it had come from.The captain of HMS Sabre warned the intruder away but it did not impact on the exercise.A Royal Navy insider confirmed the Spanish national anthem had been heard by radio operators at the Royal Navy base on Gibraltar.A source said:HMS Sabre politely requested the Spanish vessel, which is a good bit larger than she is, to leave Gibraltars territorial waters with a sovereignty warning. They extend for three miles around Gibraltar and initially it ignored the request which was made several times but she did eventually sail away after a couple of hours.Screenshots from shipping websites show how Tornado left the Spanish port of Ceuta yesterday morning before doubling back and heading towards Gibraltars Europa Point, clearly entering the exercise area.The rocky outcrop has been a British territory for more than  years and has been hotly disputed with Madrid and tensions have risen in the run up to Brexit.Last week colony in the UK and the EU launched into a new war of words over the Rock today as Gibraltar was branded a draft laws to give visa-free travel to Britons after March th.Downing Street swtly moved to slap down the jibe which is the latest ploy by Spain to take advantage of Brexit to stake its claim on the Rock.In yesterdays exercise - which was widely advertised by the Gibraltar authorities - ships were warned that a high speed manoeuvring and blank firing would take place.Passing ships who needed to contact the Royal Navy vessels involved were advised to use Channel  - which the Spanish did to broadcast their national anthem.A source in Gibraltar told The Sun:Spain is supposed to be a NATO ally but it now does this during an exercise - a clear infringement of Gibraltar territorial waters and it comes just weeks after they let Russian ships use their ports when they were asked not to.HMS Sabre issued a sovereignty warning to Tornado after it entered Gibraltar territorial waters and ordered her to leave immediately - there was an exercise going on and they would have known plus channel  was used to broadcast their national anthem. Its a clear provocation from Spain.Last night the Royal Navy referred all enquiries to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.In a statement the FCO said:We can confirm an incursion by the Spanish navy occurred this morning. As with all incursions, the Royal Navy challenged the vessel. When challenged, the Spanish navy vessel subsequently left British Gibraltar Territorial Waters. Incursions are a violation of sovereignty, not a threat to it.We have no doubt about our sovereignty over Gibraltar. The UK will never enter into arrangements under which the people of Gibraltar would pass under the sovereignty of another state against their wishes, nor enter into a process of sovereignty negotiations with which Gibraltar is not content.”The Spanish Government in Madrid and the Spanish Embassy in London was also contacted for comment but there was no immediate reply.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paramedic 23 lips double in size after mystery condition leaves her struggling to breathe
story: Lydia OConnor, , can be hit by the potentially fatal symptoms at any moment without any warning.The idiopathic urticaria sufferer was previously believed to have a nut allergy, after suffering a similar reaction for six days aged .But her condition was diagnosed after she was hospitalised in ­intensive care for four days ­following a reaction last year.Lydia, from Ballincollig, in Ireland, went on to suffer head-to-toe hives for six months, ranging from the size of a pin-prick to covering her stomach, and at their worst forcing her to go to hospital every week.Her symptoms mysteriously disappeared in August, leaving her relieved but also fearful they could come back at any point.The student, who lives in Chelmsford said: I came out in a rash from head to toe, it happened in an evening almost straight away.My lips definitely doubled in size, it was terrying because I didnt know what was happening.When I was admitted to the ICU, I thought I was having a severe allergic ­reaction like anaphylaxis, because I was struggling to breathe, and my tongue and lips were so swollen.Medication took down the ­swelling but the next day it all came back while I was in ­intensive care, then it continued to repeat over and over again.After five days in hospital and tests, the allergen markers in my blood werent raised, which ­indicated that it wasnt an allergic reaction. I was told Ive idiopathic urticaria, meaning it can start without a cause.Lydia was completely debilitated by the bizarre allergy, which affected all of her limbs. Yet despite trying everything she could think of to eliminate potential ­triggers, she couldnt find a cause.She explained: The daily rashes affected my whole body, I would wake up with them every day, they were really itchy and large.They even covered the palms of my hands and soles of my feet, it made me feel unwell, as I was so exhausted from being unable to sleep due to being so itchy.I couldnt see any identiable causes — I changed my bedsheets, my diet, my body wash, shampoo, make-up and everything.Thankfully, the rash started to subside in August — and has now disappeared ­completely. However, she constantly fears that the mystery condition will ­reappear.She said: Im worried it will come back next year as it started during the cold spell in the UK, so I do wonderits related to snow and cold weather.Im delighted that I dont have to deal with it any more — training to be a paramedic is full on and when youre with the public, people commentDuring Lydias battle with the rashes, strangers have treated her dferently.She explained: You could see people looking at my rash hoping they didnt catch it.No one said anything until when I was on ambulance ­placement — where you wear short sleeves — so could see my arms and chest.When I went to take someones blood pressure, she told me, Dont touch me, I dont want to catch it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ovarian cysts kate beckinsale rupture
story: The Hollywood A-lister was taken to hospital when she had one that ruptured last month.But researchers at ­Imperial College London found there is usually a  one in  chance of the fluid-filled sacs bursting.The findings came after a two-year study of , women with benign cysts.They warned against “unnecessary” surgery which risks complications after finding   per cent of cysts fixed themselves. Only . per cent developed into oian cancer.The experts recommended a watchful waiting alternative to surgery that involves regular monitoring with ultrasound scans.Lead researcher Professor Tom Bourne, from Imperial College London, said: Our results may lead to a paradigm sht resulting in less surgery for non-cancerous oian cysts  on condition that trained ultrasound examiners reliably exclude cancer.Oian cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop in a womans oy.They are common and typically cause no symptoms, but in some cases can trigger pelvic pain and bloating.Some oian cysts turn out to be cancerous tumours and have to be surgically removed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weather forecast news uk met office storm today
story: Skies will be blanketed with wall-to-wall cloud cover theand breadth of the country on Wednesday, according to the Met Office.And this could lead to outbreaks of rain especially in the North West and Scotland - and some of these could be wintry.Thankfully, the blanketing effect of the cloud cover will see temperatures hit a more comfortable high-single-figures for much of the UK on Wednesday.The latest forecast from Meteogroup UK said: A bright start for many, although it will be wet in the far south-east and there will be wintry showers in western Scotland.Through the day, most will become cloudy and showers will become more extensive in Scotland and Northern Ireland.Central parts will be mostly dry and bright. A breezy day.For tonight, the forecast adds: It will be a cloudy start for most with rain in the south, west and north-west.There may be a few clear spells initially in the north-east.However, through the night, most will become cloudy.Outbreaks of rain will spread eastwards through the night, affecting most parts. Moderate southerly winds.The dull, grey day comes ahead of storm that is set to batter Britain with mph gales and lashing rain.A zone of low pressure from the Atlantic is sweeping brisk winds across the country from the west, bringing a week of nasty weather.Weather forecasters have warned the rest of this week will be filled with unsettled weather.A Met Office weather expert said: Friday the storm will be at its peak as wind speeds reach mph in the most exposed parts of the west.And the weekend will get off to a dreary start.Freezing fog and gales aside, temperatures have been ing to normal for February, with up to C expected in the South West, up to C in the South East and Midlands and C in Scotland.Simon Partridge, from the Met Office, added: It is definitely back on track in terms of temperature, where they should be for the time of year, back to a more traditional UK winter for at least a week.The rest of the week is just more unsettled weather.The warmer temperatures come after a low of -.C was recorded at Chillingham Barns in Northumberland in the early hours of Sunday morning, the Met Office said.But while it was the coldest night of the year so far in England it was not as cold as parts of Scotland, where temperatures fell as low as minus .C at Braemar in the Highlands.The warmer spell ahead wont last for long, as forecasters warned Britain is set to be hit with a -C Valentines freeze too cold for gritters and yet MORE heavy snow.February  could be the coldest weather for NINE years as icy conditions .Forecaster Simon Partridge said: “We’ve got a lot more winter to get through.Most forecast models agree temperatures will dip again from around February  onwards.”The wintry conditions are expected to continue into the half-term break from February .Forecasters warned that the Atlantic low pressure systems will track further to the south, bringing slightly wetter conditions across the UK.The Met Office warned: There is the possibility that frontal systems may bring wintry hazards, particularlya more east or northeasterly flow develops.Temperatures overall around the average.They added: We spent last week on the cold side of the jet stream. Its going to be much milder this week as the jet stream moves north, driving wet and windy weather our way.

title: toby carvery customer sparks debate about perfect roast potato with complaint about overcooked spuds
story: Laura Heskett was gutted when her party were offered the blackened potatoes as part of their £. all you can eat roast dinner in Ramsgate, Kent.Alongside a photo of the charred chow on Facebook, Laura fumed: “Toby Carvery expecting us to eat roasties like this!”But while some roast lovers backed Laura’s moan – others were quick to give her a mouthful.Maria Parker added: “Roasties….Crematies surely ”But Janet Rankin joked: “I’d eat them well done.”Ria Baldoc said: “I must be weird I love potatoes like that!”Gary Hillman said: “So you pick up burnt potatoes at the carvery counter out of the many that are there and you can choose from and think we are dumb ”Karina Barker said: “We ate there tonight and the roast potatoes were lush, I like mine crispy like that.“ButI didn’t, I just wouldn’t have picked them. There was another choice - don’t get the potatoes.”Johnny Higgs replied: “Yes, because that’s why you have a roast dinner. To not have roast potatoes.”Peter Emmerson-Darnell said: “That is one disgusting plate of and I use the term loosely...food!!”Laura’s original post showed the spuds nestling between what looks like mashed potato or caullower and meat, alongside a dollop of mayonnaise.After Facebookers accused her of making it up – she hit back: “The ones that came out after looked okay but they expected everyone to eat these first there was no other choice.“Please don’t insult my intelligence by thinking I would pick these over nicer ones.“Obviously the whole lot looked like this trust me I picked the least burnt ones believe it or not.“Clearly these were the potatoes they were serving even the waitress was disgusted and gave us one meal free.”Toby Carvery has been contacted for comment.

title: kate middleton prince george princess charlotte playdates
story: The Duchess of Cambridge said she was passing her love of the arts onto her two eldest children - with five-year-old Prince George even inspired to use charcoal from a fireplace to draw her a picture.The mum-of-three, who studied a master of arts degree in art history at St Andrews University, beamed as she chatted about to staff and students during a school visit yesterday.Kate, , admitted she loved art, saying: Its something Im loving doing with the children - papier mache - I forgot how messy it is, but its really great.She also said her son George had picked up on her love of art - already delving into his creative side.The duchess recounted how the young future king had found a piece of charcoal in a fireplace and told her: Mummy Im going to draw a picture.She explained: Thats whats so nice, you can do it from all around you.And Kate even gave a sneak peek into her fashion sense as the class learnt about dferent types of printing.As Andria Zafirakou, named as the worlds best teacher, discussed fashions, Kate laughed and added: Im desperate to go back to tie dye.Kates visit to Lavender Primary School in Enfield, North London and Alperton Community School in Brent, North West London, marked Childrens Mental Health Week - a subject close to her heart.The -year-old has previously spoken out about the importance of supporting kids mental health, encouraging them to be comfortable in their own skin.And during her visit yesterday, Kate discussed what could be achievedchildren turned off the Internet and instead got creative.Shown students artwork, the impressed mum said: This is what you can doyou dont use social media - a fantastic advert.Earlier Kate produced a treasured family photo when she joined a group of primary schoolchildren asked to take in an object that makes them happy.The picture, taken at Amber Hall in Norfolk last year, shows the Cambridges posing with their children George, Charlotte and Louis and was first released as their family Christmas card.She told pupils, as she took the photo out of her purse: This is a photograph of my family, these are my children and this is my husband, and my family makes me happy - we like playing outside together and spending lots of time together and that makes me happy.She was dressed in a green £, Eponine dress with £ LK Bennett boots for the chilly day out.Ms Zafirakou, who was awarded a million dollarsin prize money and the  Varkey Foundation Global Teacher Prize, praised the royal visit to her school.Commenting on Kates admission she does art with her children she said: So shes a very hands on mum who understands about being creative - its just brilliant and lovely to hear that and as a mother myself I know exactly what that means.She stressed how the school supports not only the pupils academic aspirations but their personal development.Our approach is that were not an exam factory type of school, we do look at the childrens well-being and prepare them for their futures and also how to look after themselves.And I dont think we would ever survivewe dont have that approach.

title: boy plays piano london st pancras station
story: The boy sat at a piano in London St Pancras station and began playing a complex tune, inducing spontaneous applause from passers by who stopped to listen.In a video of the musical performance the boy can be seen losing himself in song before standing up to face the crowd gathered around him, looking bemused.Organist Gwen Mtambirwa, who witnessed the event, said the boy was - years old at most, possibly a bit younger.She said: certainly when he turned round and smiled at his dad he didnt look that old.Gwen posted a video of the talent to Twitter with the caption: Just occasionally some utter joy happens on the pianos at St Pancras...At St Pancras train station in North London there is always a piano which the public are welcome to play.Videos of talented musicians trying their hand on the instrument often go viral online.Gwen added: I heard him finish off another piece as I walked through to get my train, but hed jumped off and run back to his parents he ran back to the piano - so I stopped and listened - hedrew quite a crowd.Shame my phone sound wasnt great - gave me goosebumps.Other Twitter users replied to Gwens tweet to express their joy at hearing such a talented young musician.Helen Brough wrote: There are some piano players that are really quite brilliant ...it certainly changes your mood instantly.And Jeremiah Gooner said: What a talent, he can barely touch the pedals, superb.Meanwhile others commented on the unrealistic expectation for other kids to match his talent.Peter Chingaipe wrote: The guy with the kidon his shoulders took one quick look and swtly moved along. Good idea that, no need to raise ridiculous expectations on the boy at an early age.And another wrote: Poor kid. Bet his parents are a nightmare.

title: no deal brexit would be fault of stubborn eurocrats playing hardball top brexiteer storms
story: Chris Grayling launched a barnstorming attack on Brussels sayingwe left without a deal they would be entirely to blame, and not us.Just hours before it was revealed that Theresa May will dash to Brussels this week for talks with the EU over her deal, he said that Britain was doing all it could to try and reach agreement.But he warned in an interview with The Daily :  If they are not willing to compromise,theyre not willing to work with us to find common ground - it will be down to themthere is no deal.And he added: We want to work with the EU to reach a deal butthey are not prepared to do that - they will have to take responsibility that we are heading towards a no-deal exit.The EU have repeatedly insisted that they wont budge on the Irish border - saying the deal is done and dusted.He insisted Mrs May would be tough in the upcoming talks, but that there would be no chance of Article  being delayed at all.Ive been in every Cabinet meeting and theres been no conversation about delaying post-March , he said.We are not delaying Article .And Mr Grayling also slapped down scaremongering reports of food shortages after we leave the EU by saying: No, Im not stockpiling.Trade would continue to flow freely after we leave no matter what happens, we insisted.So its not a case that once we leave the EU that food supplies will suddenly dry up.His comments were echoed today by ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab.In an interview with ConservativeHome this morning he said that: It will be important for people to see thatthe EU remain stubbornly intransigent, they are the ones courting the WTO exit.People understand that we need to leave on th March. Whether they voted Leave or Remain, the one thing you hear is get this thing done and dusted.Leaving without a deal wouldnt be the end of the world, but it wouldnt be a walk in the park, he said, which is also the view of Roberto Azevedo, the Director of the World Trade Organisation.Mr Raab even hinted that Britain could be SAFER after Brexit - because well be able to refuse entry to anyone that border officials are worried about.Britain is due to leave the EU on March  no matter what happens, but the PM has promised to go back and ask for changes to the hated Northern Irish backstop.Mrs May is still clinging to her deal, but accepts that MPs dont want it in its current form.She will come up with the plan to take to Brussels later this week which involves major changes to the Northern Ireland border.

title: brexit secret high tech irish border
story: Officials from DexEU have been quietly working on the blueprint – drawn up by Japanese firm Fujitsu – for  months.But, it has been rapidly dusted down in the last week after MPs voted to replace the current Irish backstop with a dferent one that could involve “alternative arrangements”.An  page briefing on the explosive Futitsu plan has been leaked to The Sun.Named the ‘Drive Through Border Concept’, it ensures there is no need for any physical checks on the border or hard infrastructure.Instead, a tracking system monitors vehicles on designated routes as they cross from Northern Ireland to the Republic via GPS as well as number plate recognition cameras.Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay is studying the plan closely.It has also been circulated among a working group of senior Tory Leavers and Remainers who have come together to propose a new backstop based on stand-off customs checks, dubbed the Malthouse Compromise.EU critics of the alternative arrangements to change the backstop have claimed the technology doesn’t yet exist to police the border and are years away.But The Sun’s revelation today heaps more pressure on PM Theresa May to agree to push the border plan during talks in Brussels tomorrow.The Sun has also learned that the working group has also been briefed on a goods tracking system in Africa that has used the same technology for the last  months.Designed to ward off bandits and hijackers, the Regional Electronic Cargo Tracking System operates across borders between Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda.A Tory minister involved in the talks told The Sun: “Given that we can land a probe the size of a fridge on Mars, it can’t be beyond us to devise an imperceptible system for a  mile border”.Fujitsu have promised DexEU that proof of concept trials on the border with  hauliers testing their system will be ready by March .Marked ‘Restricted – Commercial in Confidence’, the document also reveals the plan allowsProof of concept ready for a trial by March ,  hauliers to test itThe only infrastructure needed to run the system are number plate recognition cameras on approach roads to the border itself.But that could anger nationalists who will say it break Mrs May’s promise of no infrastructure at all.The Fujitsu system could also be rejected by the Northern Irish, who have a deep dislike of state surveillance that dates back to the Troubles era.A DExEU spokesperson said: Throughout this process the Government has explored options with firms and experts for proposals to solve the issue of the Irish border.As the Political Declaration makes clear, the UK and the EU have committed to exploring what alternative arrangements to the backstop might look like. We are also clear that those solutions can not include new border infrastructures.”THE French last night told Transport Secretary Chris Grayling he was not welcome at Calais after he announced plans to ert ferries from the port under a no deal Brexit.The head of the French port Jean-Marc Puissesseau said he was never welcome toto the port as he accused Mr Grayling of being “completely disrespectful” for failing to forewarn the French about his contingency plans.The Sun revealed in October that Mr Grayling had drawn up plans to lease space on ferries so the Government can redirect them to Rotterdam and Belgian ports in case of logjams at Calais.Mr Puissesseau said the Transport Secretary gave no warning about the proposals - despite attending a meeting with port officials who insisted they could cope with extra customs checks that would be neededBritain crashes out of the EU without a deal.The French port chief told the : “Mr Grayling came to us in November and asked uswe would be ready. We told him ‘yes’, though we did not know as much as we know today. He did not tell us that he wanted to reduce the activity [at Calais].“It is not fair at all, it is completely disrespectful. I don’t want to see him again.”Mr Puissesseau added that Calais had injected fresh cash for a new traffic light system that will help combat logjams under a no deal Brexit.Green will be for lorries that have the correct paperwork, amber for those who are not sure and red for vehicles with no paperwork.He joked that Mr Grayling was so unpopular that he would also have to pass throught the traffic light systemhe did attempt to visit Calais.Mr Puissesseau said: “I have heard he is ‘failing Grayling’...He will have to have a declarationhe comes to Calais. He will have to go through the orange lane.”The anti-Brexit Best for Britain group last night said the move effectively meant Mr Grayling was “banned” from Calais.One of its supporters and Labour MP Virendra Sharma said: “Surely this is peak Chris Grayling - only this time he’s gone international.“All he needs to do now is release a statement blaming everyone  and his predictable path of chaos will be complete.”A spokesman from the Department for Transport said: “While the Transport Secretary strongly supports work across Government with the EU to ensure a deal is reached, he will also continue to lead the DfT to ensure all contingencies are prepared for concerning Brexit.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit sir keir starmer immigration
story: Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said he believed most people would accept free movementEU nationals had a job to come to.And he insisted all firms should do is advertise locally first before flying migrants in from the Continent.He added that Labour could “explore” the so-called Norway-style Brexit – where the UK would have to offer free movement to workers.Sir Keir said: “I think most people would agree thatsomebody is coming to do a job, and it needs to be done, and it’s been advertised locally beforehand with nobody to do it, then most people would say ‘I would accept that’.He added that “most people” would also accept people coming to Britain on grounds of family reunication – or study.Labour’s Election Manesto in  accepted free movement would come to an end when the UK leaves the EU.Sir Keir at the time admitted there would have to be “change” at the border.But just months later Sir Keir said Labour would accept “easy movement”.He now suggests letting any EU migrant enterthey have a job no Brit wants. Which sounds sensible enough. Except it encourages firms which have profited from cheap EU labour for years to offer rock-bottom pay they know Brits won’t take but migrants will.It’s free movement by another name. A backdoor betrayal of one of the central Brexit demands, control of our borders.Leavers are deserting Labour. Corbyn could do worse than sack his Brexit chief. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit latest eu brussels david davis theresa may
story: The ex-Brexit secretary urged the PM to hold firm as he was still confident that a deal can be done and the bloc had history of getting things done at the last moment.Theres just over  days to go until we leave the EU on March , with or without a deal.Mr Davis calmed fears when he wrote in the Dailythis morning: The EU has a history of making deals at the eleventh hour. They will always let negotiations go to the wire.Greece was denied a bailout at first but then the EU gave in and handed it three, he pointed out.The Brexiteer lashed out at the confrontational approach of the bloc and said the bloc should offer us a full free trade agreement like it has with other states like Canada and New Zealand.And he urged: This is the time for Government and Parliament to hold their nerve.There is no case whatsoever for an Article  extension. Instead, we need to insist on a deal that is mutually beneficial - not punitive - and that can be shown to work for everyone.It comes as Mrs May is in Northern Ireland again today talking to businesses and leaders about how to solve the problem of the Irish border.MPs have demanded she goes back to Brussels to rip out the hated border backstop and replace it with something .But as Brexiteers insist MPs wont accept it, so far the EU have stood firm and insisted they cant re-open the agreement.German Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to press the Irish to compromise on high tech solutions to the Irish border, it was revealed today.Shes spearheading efforts to try and get a deal over the line by getting everyone to come together.The Irish have dismissed any solutions so far, saying they dont exist or just dont work.But a source in Berlin told The Times that Mrs Merkel was very hopeful that the backstop could be solved with a combination of new technology and a sophisticated customs scheme.She is waiting for London to come forward with concrete proposals about how it would work,” the source said.Dublin will come under a lot of pressure over the coming weeks to work constructively with London.”Leo Varadkar, the Irish prime minister, has been called to Brussels today for talks with the bloc ahead of the PM flying out there tomorrow.Hes seeking aid from the EU to get Ireland ready for No Deal.Yesterday the bloc warned that Ireland faced a choice between keeping the border open to preserve the peace, and facing the prospect of a new border in the Irish sea which would see it ided from the rest of the bloc.He said this morning there was a growing desire in the bloc to do more to stop a No Deal from happening.

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: experts baffled rat creatures maggots
story: The rat-like creatures were found by the womans son who appealed to social media for help - sparking revulsion with several users.Upon seeing the video of the hairy-tailed alien like creatures, one person insisted it was like a horror movie.Sharing the video on Facebook, Tim Clerke from Auckland, New Zealand said: My mother found these on the kitchen floor this morning. One is still alive. Anyone know what they are [My we] Nikki is horried and will have nightmares for weeks!One user commented: Like someone cut the bottom end off of baby mice. Ew.Baby rats. That is like a horror movie, another said.While some guessed at deformed baby mice or miniature bats, one person guessed the creatures were rat-tailed maggots - a guess supported by some experts.According to Yahoo! insect expert Eric Edwards from the Department of Conservation in New Zealand said the creatures appeared to be hoverfly larvae, also known as rat-tailed maggots.Rat-tailed maggots - which are usually found in damp conditions and can grow up to cm - were also found last month by a backpacker in Australia.However, its reported the Biosecurity New Zealand entomology team believed the creatures to be detached legs from a large moth.A spokesperson said: They suggest that somethinghad just recently eaten the body of the moth, which may explain why a few of the legs were still twitching.

title: brexit tory cabinet ministers hold
story: NewsBrexit: Tory Cabinet ministers hold secret talks on a two-month delayMinisters have talked about a "grace period" and "extra time" to get laws through - evenTheresa Mays Brexit deal PASSESShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB NewsMinisters want a grace periodTheresa May s deal PASSES - because otherwise there wont be enough time to send necessary laws through Parliament "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCabinet ministers have been holding secret talks about delaying Brexit by two months, it is reported.They want a grace periodTheresa May s deal PASSES - because otherwise there wont be enough time to send necessary laws through Parliament. That means the plan is dferent to calls to delay Brexitthere is no deal. Any delay would need to be signed off by the EU.But with  days left to March , ministers have already talked publicly about a delay, with Foreign Secretary admitting MPs may need extra time. And today the Daily Mail andreport ministers have been discussing a delay of eight weeks, moving the date of Brexit to May .   It comes as Theresa May spends a second day in Northern Ireland today to meet Tories, Sinn Fein and the DUP in a bid to break the Brexit deadlock. The Prime Minister wants to tweak the backstop in her -page Brexit deal, which could trap the UK under EU customs rules to keep the Irish border open. She will travel to Brussels tomorrow for showdown talks with EU chiefs Jean-Claude Juncker, Donald Tusk, Antonio Tajani and Guy Verhofstadt. Mrs May hopes they will agree a time limit, an exit clause or alternative arrangements to the backstop - letting MPs sign off her deal on February . But EU chiefs have repeatedly made clear they will not rewrite the backstop.   And Irish premier Leo Varadkar - who has led public opposition to backstop changes - is holding crunch talks with EU Council President Donald Tusk today. Mrs May is said to have slapped down ministers discussing the extra time plan at Cabinet yesterday, saying it is counter-productive to talk about it as talks with the EU stall just  days before Brexit. She is busy examining a plan dubbed the Malthouse compromise that would replace the backstop but drive a coach and horses through EU red lines. Meanwhile a high-tech solution for the Irish border is under consideration again by the government - despite breaching many of the red lines about Northern Irelands future. The Drive Through Border Concept by Japanese firm Fujitsu would use numberplate recognition cameras to track vehicles crossing into the Republic. But this would involve exactly the kind of infrastructure on the border that Theresa May has refused in the past, and warned could be vandalised.  As time ticks closer firms and iniduals have been warned to prepare for No Deal. And today housebuilder Redrow warned Brexituncertainty is starting to eat into its sales, despite posting a solid rise in profits.  The group reported a % rise in sales to pound million in the six months to December  while pre-tax profit rose % to pound million. However, Redrow said sales were negatively affected towards the end of the calendar year as a result of the political uncertainty surroundingBrexit and the effect of high stamp duty tax.

title: damning report blasts tories in
story: NewsDamning report blasts Tories in denial over council cuts - hours after they vote through new onesWith perfect timing, the Public Accounts Committee has savaged the government for slashing libraries and youth work - hours after it was, yet again, accused of slashing council fundsShareByDan BloomOnline Political EditorGavin Cordon:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe PAC warned non-legally-essential services like libraries are being sidelined in cuts "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA damning report has blasted the Tories for being in denial over council cuts - hours after they voted through a new set of cuts for next year. MPs on the Public Accounts Committee spoke out just moments after the House of Commons approved town halls   budget in a huge row. Communities Secretary James Brokenshire boasted the package will give town halls a fairer future as core spending power will rise by pound.bn to pound.bn.But the actual revenue support grant from the government is being cut by pound.bn, Labour say - with officials having to make up the dference from council tax.Shadow Communities Secretary Andrew Gwynne last night accused ministers of dressing up a cut as a rise like Alice Through The Looking Glass. Now, with perfect timing, expert MPs on the PAC have accused ministers of being in denial over the perilous state of local government finances in England.  In a damning report the PAC warned councils were under enormous pressure just to main essential services such as adult and childrens social care. And it warned the governments response had been short-term fixes to keep councils going, but with a disturbing lack of a clear plan for the future. Over the past eight years, central government funding to English local authorities has been cut by almost half, the PAC said. Meanwhile demand for services has risen, with the rate of looked-after children at  year high following a number of social care scandals. Between - and -, council spending on services fell by .% in real terms. And the Local Government Association estimates authorities face a pound. billion shortfall by -.  The Government responded by announcing a pound. billion cash injection in the Budget in October. But with half the money due to be spent before the end of the current financial year, the PAC said the government had been unable provide assurances it would be used effectively. And it warned outlets like libraries and youth services are being sidelined to prioritise the basic services councils have to provide by law. Some councils are now in an extremely worrying position, PAC warned. Overspending their budgets for social care, reducing key services, falling back on financial reserves and increasingly relying on generating other sources of income, which comes with greater risks. The committee chairwoman Meg Hillier said: The Government is in denial about the perilous state of local finances.  It insists the sector is sustainable yet is unwilling or unable to back up this claim. Flimsy assertions have no place in financial planning. Government needs to get real, listen fully to the concerns of local government and take a hard look at the real impact funding reductions have on local services. And then it needs to plan properly for the long-term. Richard Watts, Chair of the Local Government Association’s Resources Board, said: Funding cuts and demand pressures are pushing local services to the brink. “The Spending Review will therefore be make or break for vital local services and securing the financial sustainability of councils must be the top priority. If we truly value our local services then we have to be prepared to pay for them. Communities Secretary James Brokenshire said the current settlement would pave the way for a fairer, more self-sufficient and resilient future for local government. That is why local authorities will have more control over the money they raise and a real terms increase in their core spending power, he said. The settlement also recognises the pressures councils face in meeting growing demand for services and rewards their impressive efforts to drive efficiencies and rebuild our economy.

story: NewsHermit living in Scottish forest saved after SOS signal is picked up in TexasThe mans emergency alert from his log cabin near near Fort Worth, Scotland, was detected , miles away in Houston, Texas, USAShareCommentsByMirror:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe man was winched away by mountain rescue workers after being found "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA hermit living in a remote forest in Scotland was rescued after his distress signal was picked up nearly , miles away. The elderly man, believed to be in his s, had lived alone in a log cabin near Fort Worth for many years. But he activated a distress beacon to send an SOS signal to tell emergency services he was in trouble. It was picked up , miles away at the International shyEmergency Response Coordination Centre in Houston, Texas, and relayed to the UK Coastguard. With no means of finding outit was a  alarm, the shyCoastguard sent up a helicopter from Prestwick, Ayrshire. A winchman found the man seriously ill in his cabin but the surrounding trees prevented him from being winched up. A mountain rescue team was instead sent in to bring him to a suitable area for winching.   Team leader John Stevenson said: “We got a call to take seven of us by helicopter to as close as the aircraft could land. “We reached the dwelling and took him by stretcher to the helicopter. “It was a cold night and the job took about  minutes. It was a very well coordinated rescue.” The pensioner was flown to Torlundy, where he was taken by shyambulance to hospital in Fort William. His condition was not known last night. Neil Blewett, aeronautical operations centre controller for HM Coastguard, said: “The satellites and the SPOT beacon saved his le because without any of those, we would not have known he needed urgent help.”

title: mum too fat theme park
story: NewsMum too fat for theme park at  stone loses over THIRD of her body weightJenefer Gillam, , from West Sussex, saw her weight creep up after gorging on huge portions of quick-fix caloric food like ready-made pies and family sharing packs of crispsShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyErin Cardf:,  FEB NewsJenefer wanted to change her le after catching a glimpse of herself in the mirror at work "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who says she was too fat for theme park rides at  stone made an incredible transformation after losing more than a third of her body weight. Jenefer Gillam, , saw her weight creep up after gorging on huge portions of quick-fix caloric food. The NHS worker, from East Preston, West Sussex began experiencing breathlessness, aching joints and indigestion - and decided to overhaul her whole lestyle in  after catching a glimpse of herself in a lt at work. Jenefer said: I just thought – ‘Jenefer, you’re enormous. Determined to change, Jenefer, whose partner Glenn, , is a technology sales consultant, joined WW, formerly known as Weight Watchers, in early  and has since completely changed her diet - slimming down to a size  after an eight stone weight loss. Jenefer, mum to Ethan, , and Eva, seven, revealed: “Since losing the weight, I’ve bumped into colleagues from dferent offices, or friends that I don’t see regularly, and they haven’t even recognised me. I’ll get a blank look when I say hello, before they realise who I am.”   Struggling with her weight for much of her le, the super-slimmer admitted to embarking on ious dferent diets over the years, without much success. Her problem escalated after having children and when, in , she started studying for a Masters degree, juggling lectures with work and being a mum meant any notion of healthy eating and exercise took a back seat. She explained: “The weight crept on as I’d be sitting there in the evenings studying and grabbing quick fixes. “I did also eat fruit and vegetables and wasn’t one for takeaways or anything like that, but it was more the portion sizes that were the problem. My portions would be huge.” Most mornings, Jenefer would start with peanut butter on toast, before grabbing a coffee and a cake or bacon butty once she got to college. Then lunch would be a cheese-laden panini followed by comfort food for dinner, like a jacket potato piled high with toppings, or a pie. “I had a terrible crisp habit, too,” she said. “I could easily get through a family bag, then fib about it, saying the kids had eaten it.” Eventually, Jenefer reached her heaviest weight of st lb – although she said she still felt relatively confident.   But, in late , everything changed during a seemingly routine morning at her work in clinical services for the NHS. After taking the lt to avoid the stairs, she saw herself in the mirror and felt asshe was seeing the change in her body for the first time. “I thought to myself, ‘You’re fat, you’re getting out of breath easily – you have to do something.’ I’d been getting all sorts of health problems like aching knees and ankles, terrible indigestion and high cholesterol,” she said. “I knew I had to change for the sake of my kids. It was never about confidence. Even at my biggest, I always tried to make the best of myself with makeup and having my hair done – but I didn’t want anything to happen to me. I had to think of Ethan and Eva.” But, since joining WW, she has now lost eight stone and, at the end of , also started regularly working out at a local gym. “It does take courage to walk in there when you aren’t a skinny Minnie, as you worry what people will say,” she said. “I started out with quite gentle exercise, but now I go five times a week and do more high intensity classes like spinning. “I never thought I’d be able to do that.” Her body overhaul has also meant Jenefer has more fun with her children.   “The best thing about it is being able to keep up with the kids more. I can go swimming with them, or bike rides at the weekend, she said. “We can even go to theme parks now, when, on two occasions in the past, I was too heavy for the rides and had to get off. It was the most mortying thing – one of those moments where everybody is staring, and you just want the ground to swallow you up. “Now, I don’t even have to think about it.” With the help of the WW app, Jenefer has transformed her eating habits too, downloading healthy recipes and ensuring she eats a balanced diet, aided by their Smartpoints system. The apps built-in barcode scanner also means Jenefer is able to check food whilst in the supermarket to see how many points it would be worth - and can even win prizes for sticking to her plan through WWs new WellnessWins reward programme.   Now, breakfast will be nutrient-packed overnight oats - a favourite with fitness bloggers - followed by fresh home-cooked meals, such as butternut squash shepherds pie or garlicky chicken with vegetables. “I have a busy le, but this regime is manageable for me. I can find recipes I like and make them quickly and easily,” she said. “Now, when I look back, I can’t quite believe it’s me in old photos. I walk much taller these days and feel very proud. “For my th birthday just gone, I even wore a black sleeveless jumpsuit. It’s something I never dreamed I’d see myself in, but I felt fantastic.”For information, visit www.weightwatchers uk

title: pub owners brutal takedown customers
story: NewsPub owners brutal takedown of customers one-star TripAdvisor reviewThe owner of the Hobgoblin in Bishopston, Bristol, delivered a scathing response to a review of the pubShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Hobgoblin pub in Bishopston, Bristol"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA customer who left a one-star TripAdvisor review of a pub was given short shrt by the landlord in a blistering response. The customer had allegedly claimed she was a police officer and that her human rights were violated when staff refused to give her a free round of drinks when she dropped the previous round on the floor. She later took to TripAdvisor to claim that the pubs staff had taken a disliking to her group and had an issue with happy people, Bristol Live reports.In his scathing riposte, landlord James Aylfe asked the woman, Hows the head this morning , and claimed she had been kicked out of the Hobgoblin pub in Bristol. His reply is serving as another example of bar and restaurant owners hitting back at bad reviews.   The woman, registered on TripAdvisor as ‘Chloe A’ posted on the public review website on Saturday night after allegedly being kicked out of the venue.Her review was headed ‘unreasonable’, and complained the bar staff took her for being drunk, even though she said she wasn’t. She explained how she and four friends had entered the pub but her stay did not last long. “The staff took a disliking to us the second we walked in,” she wrote. “We are a group of five who haven’t seen each other since uni. “They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishment. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people,” she added. At least that is the best interpretation of what Chloe A wrote on TripAdvisor, Bristol Live reported.She actually tapped in: “The staff good a disliking to use the second we walked in. We are a group of  who haven’t seen us since uni. They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishmst. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people.” Hobgoblin owner James saw the review the next day, and claims he immediately recognised who Chloe A was from the night before. He decided to respond to set the record straight, and also back up his staff, who were allegedly left upset by the experience of dealing with Chloe.   James response on TripAdvisor began inquiring after her health, before saying she might not be able to remember exactly what happened. He explained things began well - she was served a round of drinks with no problem. But then Chloe A’s time in the Hobgoblin took something of a downward turn almost immediately, because as she carried them back to the table, she spilt all the drinks after ‘stumbling away from the bar, barging into another customer’ And it was at this point, according to James, it started getting a little weird, and rather unpleasant for the staff behind the bar. She ed to the bar and ‘aggressively demanded’ replacement drinks for free, James wrote. “At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff,” he wrote, followed up by a scathing remark. “You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . “You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights,” he added. But James went on to explain the effect this behaviour had on staff and other customers. One member of staff was reduced to tears, other customers complained about her behaviour, he said. And when the assistant manager asked Chloe A to leave, she was not going to go quietly. According to James, she ‘continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights’. “So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person,” he added, before ending by stating he was ‘completely comfortable’ with how she was treated by his staff, and suggesting that she should perhaps come to the bar with an apology. Since he posted the response on the pubs Facebook page, it has gone viral. Bristol Live has messaged Chloe A, but is yet to receive a response. James said he took the decision to share his response as a show of support for the staff involved. We dont get many one-star reviews, in fact I think hers was the just the third, so mercully we havent particularly suffered from reviews like this, he told Bristol Live . I didnt want to make a big deal about it, but I didnt feel I could just leave it unanswered. What has been really nice is that the response from customers has been almost universally positive - its been really nice to see, and nice for the staff, becauseyou get a slightly unpleasant experience it can knock your confidence in dealing with people. What was also good was that a number of people commented that they were there and that the staff did really well and acted properly, he added. James Aylfes response in full Hi Chloe, Hows the head this morning  Id be surprisedyou can actually remember your behaviour last night so, just in case its a little foggy, lets have a recap, shall we  Although you were initially served a round of drinks, after you stumbled away from the bar and barged into another customer, dropping your drinks on the floor, we began to realise that you werent *entirely* sober. This assessment was further strengthened when you ed to the bar, aggressively demanding that your spilt drinks be replaced for free. You were refused. At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff. You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights. In the cold light of this morning these were rather obviously the angry ravings of someone well in their cups but as funny as it sounds now, you were extremely aggressive and intimidating at the time. A number of other customers commented that your behaviour was inappropriate, and you reduced the member of bar staff to tears. Once we had discussed what had happened, we decided that frankly it would be bestyou all moved on and we informed you that we wouldnt be serving you any further. Instead of leaving quietly with your friends you continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights. So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person. Im really not sure that paints you in a particularly flattering light either way and I am completely comfortable with how you were dealt with last night. As for where we go from here, Ill leave that up to you. Id suggest contrition and heartfelt apology as a bare minimum requirement to you being served here againbut you are, of course, free to seek to enforce your *ahem* human rights in the courtsyou are so determined. James

title: touching way prince philip told
story: NewsTouching way Prince Philip told Queen her le had changed forever following dads deathKing George VI died on February , , and his eldest daughter succeeded him to the throneShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB NewsPrince Philip and the then Princess Elizabeth on their trip to Kenya "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn February , , the Queens le changed forever. Her beloved father, King George VI passed away in his sleep and she became the Queen. When the news was broken to Princess Elizabeth she was enjoying a holiday in Kenya with her husband, Prince Philip. The evening before, she had been taking pictures of the incredible wildle from their tree top hideaway, including baboons, elephants and even a warthog. The princess had even asked to eat her evening meal outside in the Treetops hotel so she could continue to take photographs into the night.   And she had even woke early the next day to capture two rhinos fighting at a watering hole nearby. The couple got ready to depart for the next stage of their tour, which should have also taken them to New Zealand and Australia. But first they were travelling to a fishing lodge called Sangana some  miles away. Back in England, at Sandringham, the Kings staff were preparing to wake him for the day. Despite his recent bout of ill health, he had been happy the previous day and had even been on a shoot with a friend.   His final acts were to play with his two grandchildren, Charles and Anne, and have dinner with his youngest daughter, Princess Margaret. James McDonald, the Kings valet, realised something was seriously wrong with the monarch when he ran him a bath and he didnt wake as he usually did. A doctor was called to the palace who confirmed the sad news that King George had passed away in his sleep. But the couples secluded and isolated location meant it was almost impossible to break the terrible news to the princess that her father was dead. Journalist Granville Roberts, who was covering the royal tour, was the first person to receive the news in Kenya.  After it had been announced the country, Roberts spotted a breaking news memo from Reuters confirming that the king was dead. He immediately told Prince Philips private secretary, Commander Michael Parker, who tuned into the BBC to confirm the news. The Duke of Edinburgh had been taking an afternoon nap and was stunned when he was woken told the sad news. And Prince Philip now had to work out how he would tell his we the tragic news that the father she adored had died and she was now Queen. Rather than tell his we in a formal setting, surrounded by their staff, Philip took her for a walk in the grounds of the lodge they were staying in.  It was a private moment for the couple while Elizabeth could be alone with her husband during her moment of grief. She was just -years-old. Ever aware of her public duty, Elizabeth immediately discussed the practicalities of herto England. But she also asked for an hour alone in her room. The Queenswas delayed for several hours due to a storm. Her staff also realised her mourning outfit had already been sent on by plane to the next stop on her royal tour.  When the royal plane touched down in London, a black dress was brought on board for her to change into before she emerged to the full glare of the press and public. Prime Minsiter Winston Churchill was in the welcome party to greet Britains new queen home. Her coronation took place the following year and the first ever to be televised. Queen Elizabeth II is now the longest-reigning monarch and became the first British monarch to celebrate her Sapphire Jubilee -  years on the throne - last year.
