title: flytippers-carpeted-for-desecrating-pipers-grave
story: FLY-TIPPERS have desecrated the grave of a legendary th century piper from Peebles who met his tragic end after taking off on foot to play the pipes from Traquair to Edinburgh Castle.Locals have blasted inconsiderate dumpers who left rolled up carpets and tiles on the B granites road between Innerleithen and Gorebridge.One of the sites affected was the burial place of the itinerant piper who was known to frequent the local hostelries taking wagers that he could play any tune that a customer named.The tale goes that he played his final tune one drunken evening after taking a bet that he couldnt play non-stop on all the way to Edinburgh Castle.It is said that one of the crowd resorted to sabotage and cut a hole in the windbag of the pipes. The steep climb and extra effort required to play exhausted the piper who sat down never to rise again.It was at this very spot, midway between Innerleithen and Heriot that the piper was laid to rest.Disgusted by what he discovered on the roadside, local resident Nick Tokely said: ldquoOne of the five spots to have stuff dumped was the piperrsquos grave which is a scenic landmark. This time it was industrial amounts of carpet and carpet tiles, but its dferent items each week.

title: lottery-cash-to-expand-td1-youth-drop-ins
story: A GALASHIELS youth charity has been boosted with a windfall from the Scottish Childrens Lottery.TD Youth Hub has been awarded a pound, grant from the fund.TD Youth Hub supports young people in and around Galashiels by offering evening drop-ins, streetwork, young parents group, music projects, mentoring and physical activities.The Scottish Childrens Lottery cash will enable the charity to expand its drop-in service, which provides young people with a safe place to meet friends, speak to youth workers and relax.Douglas Ormston, TD Youth Hub Manager, said: "This grant from the Scottish Childrens Lottery is so important to our organisation."Our drop-ins provide us with opportunities to engage with young people, find out what their needs are and then plan projects and services which suit them, giving young people opportunities to shape their own positive futures.The Scottish Childrens Lottery was launched in October  to raise money for children in Scotland, with proceeds helping to improve the lives of children right across the country and make a real dference to those who need it most.Trustee Kirsteen Campbell said: ldquoI am delighted that we are able to provide funding for TD Youth Hub from the money generated from the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery, which was established in order to promote and support the development and potential of children and young people in Scotland."Thank you to those who play the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery - you are helping to support the great work that our charities undertake.

title: stobo-goes-third-generation-as-md-steps-down
story: IT is one of the most successful businesses in Peeblesshire.And after  years at the helm of Stobo Castle Health Spa, Stephen Winyard is handing over control to his two sons.The Winyard family bought the th century castle in the early s.Stephens parents Robert and Gaynor undertook a major makeover of the run-down castle - opening it as one of the countrys first health farms in .And a decade later Stephen took on the running of the business.At the height of srsquo fashion, it featured just  bedrooms with shared avocado bathroom suites, medical checks for guests and calorie-controlled meals.Since then, signicant investment has taken place and a poundmilion state-of-the-art spa extension in  led to the creation of  treatment rooms, a fully-equipped gym, saunas, steam rooms, a stunning -metre ozone-treated infinity pool and outdoor hot tubs.Guests are often found sipping bubbly between rejuvenating spa and beauty treatments, exploring the outdoor Japanese water garden or dining in the wood-led dining room.The addition of the stunning Cashmere Suite complete with cashmere lined walls and original works of Scottish art, cashmere-covered hand-made Italian beds and an opulent bathroom with its famed pound, hand-carved bath for a single piece of limestone, has proved another lure. It is widely acknowledged as the most opulent guest suite in the land.More recently, the new Ladies Restroom made the headlines as Scotlandrsquos most luxurious loos.Last year Stobo recorded a pre-tax profit of over pound million.And with planned future investment, the luxury spa resort is forecast to go from strength-to-strength.Last week Mr Winyard officially announced that he will step aside from his managing director role to become chairman of the business.But Stobo Castle will remain firmly in family hands with his son Elliot becoming managing director and other son Mitchell taking on the position of projects director.Stephenrsquos we Mandy will continue in her role as a director of the company.Stephen told us: ldquoStobo Castlersquos evolution from what was basically a derelict property, has been remarkable."My mother was chairman of the Society of Health and Beauty Therapists at the time. She had a vision that it could become a health farm, at a time when such places were virtually unheard of."Today Stobo Castle is Scotlandrsquos only destination spa and one of many peoplersquos lsquomust visitrsquo places to relax and rejuvenate."Sadly, my parents are no longer alive to see it, however its success is testimony to their incredible vision and hard work."Stobo Castlersquos staff have also contributed immensely to its success, many of whom have been here almost since the beginning.

title: scottish-borders-council-in-line-for-more-cash
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council could be in for a larger settlement grant than first expected following a deal between rival parties in Holyrood.A new funding settlement for local authorities has been agreed in the Scottish parliament following a last-minute deal between the majority Scottish National Party and minority Greens ahead of a vote on the annual budget.The deal includes more core funding for councils and extra powers for them to levy local parking and tourist taxes.Derek MacKay, the Scottish Governmentrsquos finance secretary, first unveiled proposals for the budget in December , including added funding for schools and the National Health Service, as well as increasing income tax for those earning pound, or more.Opposition parties moved to block the bid, partly due to the SNP refusing to rule out calling another independence referendum and also because they say the budget would result in a poundm funding cut for local authorities.However, the deal with the Scottish Greens means the budget is now likely to be passed.Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoThis settlement does go some way to mitigating the cuts that we were expecting. However, it has a narrow focus in terms of local taxation.ldquoGiven the consultation only concluded last Friday, it is surprising that the Scottish Government were able to announce the tourist tax today.The new deal with the Scottish Greens includes an extra poundm for the core local government settlement, a move to three-year local authority budgets and legislation that will give councils control over tourism taxes.The deal also includes raising the council tax cap, meaning local authorities will now be able to increase council tax by .%, up from %.Fellow Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, also leader of the councilrsquos Scottish national party opposition group , said: ldquoSignicant announcements have been made on a phased development of alternatives to the council tax. ldquoAlthough I donrsquot advocate that locally we should immediately take advantage of the proposal to give local authorities power to introduce a tourist tax, or the suggested workplace parking levy, these are adjustments that some Scottish city authorities will want to take up after the necessary legislation is approved.ldquoI am also pleased that talks on meaningful alternatives to council tax will restart and that with a three-year funding settlement, as opposed to the current one-year deals, there will be more clarity for local authorities on future funding.ldquoThere are also small changes in the - revenue grants for local authorities. Despite the constant chant of despair from the Bordersrsquo Tories, I said all along that the December announcements of funding for the council were only provisional. ldquoThe Conservatives who lead the council like to highlight that we were told we might see pound.m less for core revenue funding next year, conveniently forgetting to talk about promised money for new services such as the massive expansion in early learning and childcare.ldquoThey also omit to tell Borderers that we are getting poundm more next year as capital funding, almost exactly offsetting the change in revenue funding.ldquoWe must wait until the detail of the poundm package from the Scottish Government is analysed by officers, but my provisional calculation is that the new funding announcements could give the council more than pound.m, meaning that we will see a clear cash increase in next yearrsquos funding for core revenue and capital.ldquoSadly, we are being told that the Conservatives in Holyrood may vote against these welcome changes.Rachael Hamilton, Conservative MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, said: ldquoThanks to the SNP, Scots across the country are about to be hit by a triple tax bombshell.ldquoThis budget not only taxes aspiration but taxes people for driving to work, which is quite frankly ridiculous in a constituency like mine, where travelling by car is essential.ldquoWe will pay the highest income taxes in the UK, council tax could go up and now you might even be taxed hundreds of pounds a year for taking your car to work.ldquoThe SNP have run out of ideas on how to grow and expand the economy. Instead, they have decided to raid the pockets of hard-working families.,params: .pushMr Bell added: ldquoMy big message to the Borders Tories is to drop their mentality of dependence and to take responsibility for balancing a Borders budget. ldquoThe power to make change is in the hands of the council and they should stop trying to shirk local responsibility. Power to finance - expenditure is in the hands of the administration.ldquoDerek MacKay has announced that more could be raised from further increasing the local council tax to a new upper level of over %, as the Scottish Government has lted the previous cap.ldquoFurther, the Tory-led Borders administration should take responsibility for properly managing our councilrsquos affairs. ldquoFigures I have seen show that there are unrealised savings of over pound.m that were planned in last yearrsquos budget which have not been realised in practice.ldquoIf these saving had been made, then there would be less cuts this year. If we hadnrsquot poured it away in unrealised savings and could add this new money, perhaps the Bordersrsquo revenue finances would balance. ldquoWhat is the point in giving the administration any more moneythey canrsquot properly manage what we now get. They must stop blaming everyone  and put their own affairs in order.What do you think Send us your views for our letters page, including your name and address, here

title: scottish-borders-council-food-crackdown
story: A CRACKDOWN on the sale of unhealthy foods could soon be served up by Scottish Borders Council.Trading standards officers could take on a larger role policing the selling and marketing of high-fat, high-sugar and high-salt foods.In July , the Scottish Government produced a consultation paper setting out the foods they felt needed to be targeted in order to reduce the calorie intake and weight of Scots.These include confectionery, sweet biscuits, crisps, savoury snacks, cakes, pastries, puddings and soft drinks with added sugar.The consultation askslocal authorities agree with this list and whether more items should be added.The councilrsquos consultation response, drafted by Keith Allan of NHS Borders, states that the authority believes ice-cream, ready meals and dairy desserts should also be included in the crackdown, explaining: ldquoWhile it will certainly be useful to target the discretionary foods listed above, there is also a need to include drinks high in sugar, salt, fat or calories irrespective of whether or not this is added.ldquoSimilarly, ice-cream and dairy desserts should also come under the scope of the new policy as they are often high in fat and high in sugar and do not form an essential dietary component.ldquoWhile dairy-based desserts could offer some benefits in terms of calcium and other nutrients, these would be available from other sources in a healthy diet.ldquoTheir benefit in a dairy-based dessert would be offset by the high-energy density and presence of salts, sugars and fats.At a full meeting of the council last Thursday, members voted in favour of approving the officerrsquos draft response despite ided opinion amongst councillors.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing , a health worker, was strongly in favour of the consultation response, saying: ldquoI have worked in the adult health service my entire adult le.ldquoAnd I have seen first hand the impact on peoplersquos wellbeing of poor diet and the suffering it causes. In my current role, there is barely a day that goes by without discussing with a parent or carer the impact of sugar in their childrenrsquos food, but, letrsquos face it, fat, salt and sugar make things taste nice, and itrsquos easy to fall into the trap of overindulgence.ldquoThatrsquos okay every now and again, but regular overindulgence of fat, sugar and salt leads to grave consequences, such as tooth decay, heart disease, diabetes and cancer.ldquoObesity, including childhood obesity, is fast becoming the epidemic of our age.ldquoMany of us are blissfully unaware just how much salt, sugar and fat is in the foods we buy.ldquoBig companies which produce, promote and retail these products are in it to maximise profits.ldquoThey have at their disposal expensive advertising and marketing which hugely influence our choices and purchasing habits.However, Galashiels councillor Harry Scottfelt the proposals amounted to unwelcome government meddling with personal choice, saying: ldquoIrsquom not in agreement with any of the proposals in this paper.,params: .pushldquoI appreciate the problem, but this is typical nanny state, dictating to us how we should live our lives.ldquoIt will cause unnecessary restrictions on business, specialist retailers will find it hard to market themselves, and I doubt very much whether it will have any impact on the groups it is targeting.ldquoWhilst Irsquom very much in favour of labelling food to make clearer to the consumers whatrsquos in it, in principle I am against compulsion.ldquoPeople have to take responsibility for their own lives and lestyle choices, and as long as you keep within the law, the state should have no place in telling you what you can eat or drink.A motion put forward by Councillor Scott called for the response to be completely rejected, but it was not supported by his fellow councillors.Instead, they opted to vote to submit the consultation response in full, albeit as a council officer response not as a political response.According to NHS Health Scotland, in ,  per cent of Scotlandrsquos children were at risk of becoming overweight and  per cent were at risk of becoming obese.That same year, title: pothole-plea-to-boost-borders-cycle-tourism
story: A SCOTTISH Borders councillor has been taking the council to task over the state of the regionrsquos roads, raising fears it could impact on the regionrsquos cycling tourism economy.Galashiels and District councillor Harry Scott has raised issues with the council about the state of the B Heriot to Innerleithen road, designated as a cycling route but, he says, in ldquoa state of serious disrepair.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday  January, councillor Scott asked for the road to be resurfaced: ldquoThe B Heriot to Innerleithen road is listed as an official Borders cycle route with the aim ofattracting touring cyclists to enjoy the scenery and spend money in the Borders.ldquoSeveral sections of the road, particularly towards Innerleithen are presently in a state of serious disrepair, and hazardous not only for cars, but particularly for cyclists.ldquoMay I ask that at the least the most hazardous sections of the B be considered for inclusion as a matter of priority in the roads departmentrsquos scheme of works and overlays for the year  .In response, Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, told the chamber: ldquoThe road is inspected every two months in accordance with the councilrsquos policy and standards guidelines.ldquoAny defects noted during these inspections are recorded and instructions are issued to carry out reactive maintenance as required within the timescale guidelines.ldquoMaintenance of the councilrsquos adopted road network is programmed by our asset team.ldquoSome sections of the B road are listed as lsquobeing considered for possible inclusionrsquo in future surface treatment programmes.ldquoUnfortunately, the overall condition of our roads network means that we are not in a position to agree to treat all identied sections with a permanent form of treatment and must apply a prioritisation process to determine an annual programme which means our annual budget.In a prepared statement, councillor Scott said: ldquoMy reasons are that we are selling the Scottish Borders to tourists, cycling being one of the strands.ldquoThe B leads from the Edinburgh and Lothians area to the heart of Borders cycling in the Innerleithen and Peebles areas.ldquoLike any tourists we hope that they will extend their stay and their exploration of the Borders from that base.ldquoThe B is no better or worse than many of our other roads, and Irsquom not looking for a quick fixes because in the current financial climate, there are none.ldquoIrsquom simply asking that the road is not forgotten in the work schedule, and that at the least the worst sections can be identied for improvement or repair.What do you think Send us your views for our title: business-brunch-whets-appetite-for-languages
story: YOUNG people from four Borders schools have taken part in a business and languages event.S and S students from Earlston High, Jedburgh Grammar, Kelso High and Peebles High joined  learners from across the Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders areas for the Business Brunch in Edinburghs Dynamic Earth.The event on January  demonstrated the relevance of language skills in a work context and aimed to encourage pupils to continue with their language studies into the senior phase of their secondary education and beyond.Pupils heard from a range of business leaders who view language skills as key to the growth and success of their company.A teacher attending the event said: ldquoTodayrsquos event has opened my learnersrsquo eyes to languages as a key skill for work in all industries, and as something to enrich their lives.One of the young people added to this, and commented: ldquoI learnt that languages are useful for everything, including my personal le. I also discovered that knowing a language makes you a lot more employable. I didnt expect places like Dynamic Earth to have languages as one of their work experience opportunities.Lynn Houmdi from Maroc-o-phile and one of the speakers, stated: ldquoThe event was really well-organised. I chatted to people on a few of the stands and was really impressed that so many companies and organisations are actively seeking language skills.Sophie Dawes, Project Officer at Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian and East Lothian regional group, and one of the organisers, stated: ldquoGiving young people an opportunity to hear directly from businesses across a broad range of sectors highlighted why continuing with languages at school could be so beneficial to opening up a world of opportunities beyond school. With a iety of industry led workshops and exhibitors speaking directly with young people, everyone had opportunities to be informed and inspired."The day was action packed from start to finish and the feedback received from young people and teachers has been so positive. Wersquore already looking forward to planning for !The event was organised by SCILT, Scotlandrsquos National Centre for Languages based at University of Strathclyde, in partnership with Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian, East Lothian, West Lothian and Borders regional groups together with the University Council for Modern Languages Scotland .Fhiona Mackay, Director of SCILT said: ldquoIn these times of uncertainty, it is even more important than ever that we equip our young people with the skills they will need for le beyond school. We want them to be outward-looking and able to operate in an interdependent world. Events such as these highlight the importance of language skills and intercultural competencies in the world of work.ldquoThe business leaders who speak at these events give of their own time because they understand how much these skills are needed and valued by employers and how vital they are for Scotlandrsquos business community. This kind of collaboration is an example of how education and business sectors can work together for their mutual benefit so that we can support young people and help them develop the portfolio of skills that employers require in their workforce.

title: msp-urges-borders-women-to-have-smear-tests
story: A REGIONAL MSP is encouraging women in the Borders to attend regular smear tests.Claudia Beamishhas joined charity Jorsquos Cervical Cancer Trustrsquos campaign to get more people going to screenings more often.She told us: ldquoLast year cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from . per cent to . per cent which means more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.ldquoYet regular screening prevents up to  per cent of cervical cancers developing.ldquoThe statistics are particularly worrying for younger women where uptake is only  per cent despite the fact cervical cancer is the most common cancer for women aged under .ldquoI know going for a smear test isnrsquot easy, it can be uncomfortable and awkward but it is so important to attend appointments and I urge people not to put them off. title: young-borderers-invited-to-compete-in-art-competition

title: melrose-farmer-drove-digger-at-university-professor-neighbour
story: A Melrose farmer drove an agricultural digger at a university professor in a neighbourly dispute, Selkirk Sherf Court has been told.James Morton was then involved in a violent struggle with police officers in a cow shed which ended upwith them falling into an animal waste pit.Details of the bizarre bust-up emerged last week when the -year-old was fined pound after admitting a charge of threatening or abusive behaviour.Graham Fraser, prosecuting, explained how there had been a long standing neighbourly dispute between the farm atKaeside, near Melrose,and the home of Dr. Britta Kalkreuter who is an professor at the School of Textiles and Design at Heriot Watt University, and her husband.At lunchtime on November  she heard a banging noise outside her home and walked down the access road with an Ipad for filming purposes to investigate.Mr Fraser explained how Morton was in a JCB with a bucket in front digging up earth and on seeing his neighbour drove at a steady speed towards her.He added:"It stopped so close to her she could physically touch the vehicle."The police were contacted but Morton would not speak to the officers when they arrived.Police officers viewed the video footage on the Ipad and took the view it was a "deliberate attempt to intimidate" the neighbour.Mr Fraser said Morton then ran off into the cow shed and was involved in a violent struggle with the officers which resulted in them falling into animal waste stored in the shed.He continued: "During the course of the struggle a set of keys came away from a constable as well as a warrant card.The keys were never found."After being cautioned and charged Morton insisted Ms Kalkreuter should have moved out of the way of the digger.Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said his client should be given a degree of sympathy as he had been engaging with the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency and had spent thousands of pounds trying to recty drainage problems in the area.He explained that Ms Kaulkreuter and her husband had reported the farm to SEPA on three occasions and theScottish SPCA four times.Mr Patrick added:"It has been going on for some time and he was at the end of his tether. He felt it was a vendetta when he saw her holding the Ipad and that it was being done to provoke him. Unfortunately he has bitten and lost the rag.He has accepted that."He explained that the incident with the police arose because Morton had panicked.Mr Patrick concluded:"He just wishes he and his neighbour could stay apart and there are legal ways to avoid this.It is a situation which needs to cool down."Morton, who has a previous conviction, had a fine of pound imposed by Sherf Adrian Cotham reduced to pound due to the guilty plea.

title: pupils-to-move-school-following-contaminated-water-find
story: ASSURANCES have been given to parents after high levels of lead were found in a school water supply.Education chiefs have also handed out bottled water to pupils at Ednam Primary School in Kelso.The high levels of lead were discovered in taps at four wash basins during routine water testing last Thursday.An immediate ban on drinking or using tap water was implemented.And alternative catering arrangements were introduced.Scottish Borders Council Chief Executive Tracey Logan told the Border : ldquoThe action taken by the council is very much precautionary but it was felt important to immediately act in order to reduce any potential risks to pupils and staff."As well as members of staff Ednam Primary School has a roll of  pupils and nine nursery children.Following mid-term holidays later this month all pupils and staff will move to nearby Broomlands Primary to allow further detailed investigations and required repair works to take place.Ms Logan added: ldquoWe are currently finalising arrangements for the move to Broomlands and we aim to ensure disruption is minimised as much as possible."We will also be keeping parents fully updated throughout this process."Health chiefs dont believe there are any serious risks to pupils and staff.Tim Patterson, Joint Director of Public Health for SBC and NHS Borders, said: ldquoWhile the risk to public health is low, all parents and others affected have been provided with public health information to help answer any health-related queries they have.ldquoIf any parents or staff have any signicant health concerns, they are advised to contact their GP in the usual manner.

title: football-club-vandals-leave-trail-of-sectarian-slurs
story: AN anti-sectarian charity has voiced its anger and concern after a vandalism attack at a local football club.Vile anti-Catholic slogans were painted onto doors, signs and windows at Vale of Leithens Victoria Park ground.And more than a dozen pro-Rangers phrases were also daubed onto the enclosure and dug-outs.It is estimated the clean-up will run into several hundred pounds.But its the repulsive sectarian slogans which have caused the most anger with some.Dave Scott, director of Nil By Mouth, tours the country educating schoolchildren about the isiveness and dangers of sectarian behaviour.And he finds it hard to believe that it is happening on his doorstep.Dave told us: "This is utterly moronic behaviour and you wouldnrsquot need two hands to count the IQ points of those behind it."As a Gala Fairydean Rovers fan Irsquove been to Victoria Park on numerous occasions and know how hard the clubrsquos committee and volunteers work to keep the Vale going and the last thing they need is having to clean up after mindless acts of vandalism."Sectarianism in the Borders is rare with minimal convictions when compared to other parts of the country.And Nil By Mouth hope this attack in Innerleithen will be a isolated incident.Mr Scott added: "As part of our Kiss Bigotry Goodbye campaign we will contact the club and offer to sponsor a game in the very near future to show that true football supporters love the game and hate this sort of nonsense."Vale of Leithens committee have already forked out thousands of pounds to bring their ground up to Lowland League standards.And they regularly have to carry out clean-ups and repairs following minor vandalism.But chairman Stuart Robertson admits this is the worst attack hes witnessed.Mr Robertson said: "This is the worst case of vandalism Ive seen in all my years of being involved at the Vale."There is paint everywhere and we are going to have to clean it off the best we can before our next game."People work so hard at Vale of Leithen yet you get people who come along and undo all the good work."Police Scotland confirmed an investigation has been launched.A spokesperson said: "Police in the Borders are investigating following a report of vandalism at a football club in Innerleithen."The incident took place between am on Friday, February  and am on Monday, February  in the Victoria Park area."Inquiries are ongoing and anyone who witnessed any suspicious behaviour in the area over the weekend of February  and , or has information that can help identy those involved, is asked to contact officers on  and quote incident number  of February ."Alternatively a report can be made to Crimestoppers anonymously on   ."

title: fundraising-begins-for-fish-shop-extension-plans-in-selkirk
story: A FRESH fundraising drive is about to begin in Selkirk to conclude work on a new community-owned shop.After lying dormant for more than two decades the former fish shop in Tower Street was brought back into use at the end of last year by the Selkirk Regeneration Company.Now the charity wants to renovate the rest of the property to turn it into a new community space.And they hope to start eating into the pound, price tag by hosting a fundraising sale later this month.David Bethune treasurer of Selkirk Regeneration Company told us: "Using virtually every last penny of our resources, we completed temporary redecoration of the front shop to allow it to be used as a second pop-up shop in the run up to Christmas."The next stage is to complete the renovation of the whole property, including rebuilding the back shop, to turn it into a fully accessible community resource."Plans have been drawn up, and while we hope most of the cost can be raised from grants, some will need to come from the community itself."During Friday and Saturday, February  and , the Selkirk Regeneration Company will hold a sale of unwanted presents and second-hand items at the neighbouring corner pop-up shop at  Tower Street.Mr Bethune added: "There will probably also be some baking and other goodies, so make sure you pop in to see what is for sale, and so help fund the renovation of the old fish shop."Anyone who would like ot donate items can hand them into  Tower Street on the Tuesday or Wednesday, February  and .Alternativelyyou would like items collected call Mr Bethune on  .

title: chloe-and-oscar-pull-on-their-hats-in-memory-of-dad
story: A BORDERS brother and sister who lost their father to a brain tumour are starring in a marketing campaign to help raise funds for finding a cure for the disease.Chloe Lowther, , and her nine-year-old brother Oscar are featuring in this yearrsquos national Wear A Hat Day campaign by the Brain Tumour Research charity.The Peebles siblings were invited to take part to represent Scotland and their images will be seen across the country as the campaign is launched ready for Brain Tumour Awareness month in March.Across the UK, other children who have either been bereaved by a brain tumour, are living with a brain tumour or have a close family member who has been diagnosed, are also taking part to represent their regions.They are all donning their best headwear from beanies to cowboy hats, trilbies to Panamas, baseball caps to novelty headpieces, and are asking others to join them for Wear A Hat Day, which takes place on Friday, March .The event is expected to smash all records as it marks its th year.Chloe and Oscarrsquos dad Matt was diagnosed after collapsing at home with an aggressive and incurable glioblastoma multormebrain tumour.Despite undergoing surgery and chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment, Matt passed away less than two years later, aged , in March , not long after his th wedding anniversary.Mum Gill, a teaching secretary at Edinburgh College of Art, said: ldquoWhen Matt was diagnosed, we were told that the average le expectancy of this type of tumour was  to  months."The grieving process for me started  months before Matt died as the two of us came to terms with the idea that we were not going to have the le together we planned."I spent a lot of time listening to a playlist we compiled which represented our  years together.ldquoNow I am doing my best to give our children the childhood we had planned together.ldquoI am so proud of Oscar and Chloe for being part of the Wear A Hat Day campaign."It means so much to my family and me to help contribute towards a cure, so itrsquos an honour to have them take part. Chloe and Oscar had such a fun time at the photoshoot too and it will be a lovely memento for them to look back on.Wear A Hat Day also has the backing of supermodel, businesswoman and brain tumour survivor Caprice who underwent surgery to remove a meningioma brain tumour two years ago.A patron of Brain Tumour Research, Caprice plays a key role in raising awareness of the disease and campaigning for the government and the larger cancer charities to increase national investment in research. Also supporting this yearrsquos fundraiser is Strictly Come Dancing finalist Debbie McGee who lost her magician husband Paul Daniels to the disease three years ago.Corporate supporters already signed up for the fundraiser include Specsavers, Hobbycraft, and Venture Studios ndash the latter worked with families across the UK who have been affected by brain tumours to create the stunning portraits used in the campaign.,params: .pushAlso taking part will be hundreds of schools, workplaces, and iniduals who will don their hat of choice and hold a whole host of hat-themed fundraising events in support of Brain Tumour Research.Sue Farrington Smith, Chief Executive of Brain Tumour Research, told us: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to Chloe and Oscar and their mum for helping us to launch Wear A Hat Day ."I know that people will be both distressed and inspired to hear the stories of all of these families who, like my own, know the pain of a brain tumour diagnosis.ldquoWe are entirely committed to easing this pain by improving treatment options for patients and, ultimately, finding a cure. Brain tumours kill more children and adults under the age of  than any other cancer yet, historically, just one percent of the national spend on cancer research has been allocated to this devastating disease Brain Tumour Research is proud to be changing this.ldquoThe sad truth is that brain tumours are indiscriminate and can affect anyone at any age and this means the impact on families is enormous. Too many children are losing siblings, parents and grandparents, too many parents are enduring the agony of their childrsquos diagnosis, and society as a whole continues to bear the burden of increased costs through the NHS, lost taxes, and demands on the benefits system.Wear A Hat Day has raised over a million pounds since the launch of Brain Tumour Research  years ago.The big day will see schools, workplaces, families and iniduals across the UK fundraising and taking part in fun events to raise awareness of brain tumours and help fund le-saving research.Funds raised will develop the charityrsquos network of brain tumour research centres in the UK where scientists are focused on improving outcomes for patients and, ultimately, finding a cure.To get involved, or donate, please visit: www.wearahatday.org or text HAT to  to donate pound.

story: Plans to establish a Scottish National Investment bank will help transform inclusive growth across Argyll and Bute.Last month, finance secretary Derek Mackay MSP announced plans for an initial investment in the bank of £ million as part of his draft budget proposals for  .Subject to regulatory and legislative approval, the national investment bank will aim to begin investing in Scottish businesses and communities from  – investing at least £ billion in its first ten years.The investment bank will provide loans of up to £ million for small to medium sized local enterprises with high growth potential.Operating within a core set of principles, the bank will deliver sustainable growth – with both iniduals and small local businesses set to benefit.Small businesses are the backbone of the Argyll and Bute economy. title: letter wild salmon migration
story: It was recently reported that the Scottish Gamekeepers Associationis calling for a ban on fish farms being built on wild salmon migration routes.The SGA fishing group believe careful positioning of proposed farms and re-siting problem pens could stop wild stocks being infested with parasites‎.Crown Estate Scotland, under the Freedom of InformationAct ‎, confirmed MOWI, formerly known as Marine Harvest, has a lease option agreement to a third site in the Kilbrannan Sound.This is a short term conditional agreement, for a secure and exclusive interest, that can be exercised for a full lease once all necessary consents # including planning permission and the marine licence have been secured.With the planned expansion, by an increase of  per cent, of the two existing MOWI sites, at Carradale and a third site at Cour Point, Kilbrannan Sound will be home to the single largest concentration of fish farm pens and salmon biomass in Europe.The SGA believe sea lice outbreaks from salmon farms contribute to the collapse of wild salmon stocks.A spokesperson said: #While a healthy salmon can survive with a burden of sealice, the high number of lice found in captive areas can lead to weakness and death.#Does Argyll and Bute Council and the Scottish Government acknowledge both the impact of sea lice and the subsequent use of chemicals, presently being felt in the Kilbrannan Sound An impact not only on wild salmon and sea trout stocks also our very localised lobster, crab and prawn fishing industry In past decades Kilbrannan Sound would have been described as a super highway for migrating wild salmon.Legislation in Norway, and recently British Colombia, does not permit the siting of fish farms on recognised wild salmon migration routes.Is it the local authority and national government#s intention to down grade the Sound, once plentul in fish and crustaceans alike, to that of a backwater trickle Tommy Macpherson,Saddell.

title: from our files january 25 2019
story: Friday January  Carradale poem at London ZooA poem created by a Carradale Primary School pupil has appeared on the front cover of a book which is set to be displayed at London Zoo.Along with Michaela Richard#s poem, pictures that were drawn by Jordan McKenzie and Raymond Gosling of primary five and Michael Charlwood of primary seven also appeared in the booklet.The frog poem folio impressed the director of the Zoological Society of London, David Field, who expressed a wish to display the poems and pictures at the zoo.The poem was read out and the pictures shown to about  people at Halting the Global Decline in Amphibians, a symposium dinner at London Zoo recently.Clockwise from left: Raymond Gosling, Jordan McKenzie, Michael Charlwood and Michaela Richards. _cfiles_Carradale_Pupils YEARS AGOFriday February  This time it#s warJoyriders face the wrath of taxi bossA Campbeltown taxi boss hopes to hunt down joyriders who stole one of his cars # by offering an award for information on the thieves.The distinctive Red Cabs vehicle # a white Montego with a red stripe, registration number D WBB # was stolen, from outside the Dellwood Hotel, around midnight last Thursday.And now Terry Meachem wants information leading to the conviction of the culprits, with £ on offer as the reward.The car was found hours later in the middle of the road to Peninver, facing Campbeltown.Red Cabs driver, and N and M Motors mechanic, Donald Brown, is pictured diagnosing serious damage to the gearbox which could cost as much as £ to repair.#Someone is bound to have seen it,# an irate Terry told the Courier, #and the money is there for information on who stole it.#Not only was the car badly damaged, but we#re losing money with the car being out of action.#This sort of thing is sickening, and whoever did it deserves all that is coming to them.#The Dellwood Hotel is at the entrance to the town on the West Road, and residents say they heard a car, believed to be the taxi, leaving at around . YEARS AGOJanuary  City honour for Mrs MacdonaldMrs Anne Maxwell Macdonald, we of Captain John Macdonald, the Laird of Largie, is to receive the freedom of Glasgow #in recognition of her deep interest in the cultural and civic le of the city.#Lord Provost Mr John Johnston proposed the honour and received the unanimous support of his magistrate colleagues. title: a kintyre music club review
story: By David O McEwanA pair of internationally recognised musicians visited Campbeltown for Kintyre Music Club#s first concert of .Cellist Jamal Aliyev from Azerbaijan and pianist Jâms Coleman, from Anglesey in North Wales, presented four pieces, at the recent Lorne and Lowland Hall event.The programme featured works by Beethoven Bloch and Bridge.The G minor cello sonata by Beethoven unfolded in typical fashion, with lots of contrasts in mood and speed, and revealed the assured technical and expressive abilities of both performers.Similarly in the Variations by the same composer it was clear that both performers were working as equals rather than as soloist and accompanist.The Bridge Cello Sonata pushed the boundaries of traditional harmonies and structure to the limits but always drew back from total dissonance.Once again the total mastery of their instruments was revealed by the performers.Perhaps the most attractive part of the programme was the #Three pieces from Jewish Le# by Bloch.These captured the spirit and soul of Judaism so well.The Swan by Saint-Saëns concluded the evening as a well-received encore.Cellist Jamal Aliyev and pianist Jâms Coleman with David O McEwan turning the pages during the concert. _cmusicclub_Jamal_Aliyev

title: down memory lane january 25 2019
story: Stephen Laing, assisted by his cousin, Glasgow academic and author Willy Maley, has found details and photographs of his aunt Anne Maley , working in the Women’s Land Army at Glenbarr during the Second World War. Anne passed away in  and her nephew has been researching family history.Stephen, who has posted a set of pictures to the Facebook page ‘Old Campbeltown and Surrounding Area,’ said: ‘Willy is the brains in our family, he’s been a great help to me. I am compiling a family tree and history.‘I have no family link to Kintyre and it was great to find out that my aunt Anne was in this area, at Rosehill Farm, in the war working on one of the farms.’In response to Down Memory Lane’s interest, Willy said: ‘That would make my mammy very happy.’In a short story Anne Maley wrote, one paragraph stated: ‘I never had any fear of animals in the old days. After all I was a land girl during the war. I worked among coos wi’ dangerous looking horns, large Clydesdales with floundering feet, and also a temperamental sheep dug. I never felt threatened.’

title: window wanderland goes under the sea
story: The theme for this year#s Magical Neighbourhood Walking Trail, on March  and , as suggested by some of CPH’s Facebook followers, is the sea.CPH is inviting everyone who has a window – houses, shop fronts, classrooms, cars, boats, sheds # to get creative and make a display according to the theme.The event is completely free and can be explored and enjoyed by the whole community, whether that is as window-makers or wanderers.The event is fun, creative, inclusive and gives the community an incentive to explore their neighbourhood on a dark winter’s evening and enjoy it in a whole new light.Window Wanderland was started in Bristol in February  by Lucy Reeves to help bring communities together, ward off isolation and spread happiness in the gloom of winter.Anyone can take part and almost anything can be a display from a string of fairy lights to a band playing in the living room, as long as it is family friendly, anything goes.There were  displays last year, when the theme was #cinema#, including a room transformed into Pandora from Avatar, a precise paper-cut Batman, hand-knitted Minions, nursery displays, balloons and inflatables in Campbeltown Town Hall, superheroes, Disney characters and much more.Cinema manager Ellen Mainwood said: #We had a great weekend last year with our first Window Wanderland. There were some brilliant displays, and people really enjoyed getting out and about to see them.#It’s fun and easy to join in, so we hope lots of people will get involved this year.#Participants get a welcome pack when they sign up and access to lots of inspiration.There will be free materials available and drop-in workshops to help window-makers with their displays at the cinema on March  and .Wanderers can see where the decorated windows are on an online map and CPH will have printed copies available during the event.Cinema staff can help window-makers sign upthey do not have access to the website or need some assistance.Those with questions, or who would like to sponsor, promote or help with the event should contact Ellen by emailing manager@campbeltownpicturehouseFor more information and to sign up, visit https:www.windowwanderland event campbeltown- A living room transformed into Pandora from Avatar. story: Our front page article about Karen Thomson Hickson#s journey through bone marrow donation, is eye-opening and inspirational.Karen gave her donation in  not knowing the identity of the recipient or even where in the world he lived.Almost five years later, she learned that her actions directly saved the le of a man from Canada, suffering from an acute form of leukemia.The recipient would undoubtedly not be alive today without her bone marrow donation but is now living a normal, healthy le.There are constant appeals from families desperate for donors to join registers in the chance they may be a match with sick relatives.Just this week the family of nine-year-old Chloe Purvis from Fort William,  diagnosed with a rare form of cancer, appealed for people to join registers such as DKMS.Most people would accept these donations, so why are so few willing to give them

title: letter kintyre needs a modern connectivity system
story: The Scottish Government is seeking views on the proposed future Glasgow to Campbeltown air service prior to it being retendered.I have discussed this specic issue with friends and we have concerns about the current unreliable ferry, air services and road link.We believe we should receive at the very least the same air service as provided to the island of Islay.We have the following thoughts on improvements to encourage new businesses to locate here and to promote tourism.We would like a larger Saab  or equivalent aircraft that can land in more adverse weather conditions # we understand the economies of scale and suggest a service that can fly to Campbeltown and then on to Islay, back to Campbeltown and ing to Glasgow, or vice versa.We would like the reinstatement of the radar system to assist landings in adverse weather conditions.As there is a separate service between Islay and Edinburgh we suggest that Campbeltown should be included as we also have key tourist attractions such as distilleries and three fantastic -hole golf courses and high-standard accommodation.We would like to see the service continue with a timetable with low ticket prices to allow the full day in Glasgow for NHS appointments, business and shopping trips and the reinstatement of seven days a week flights to enhance business and tourism.In addition, we want national advertising campaigns inclusive of timetables to promote the area for increased passenger numbers, including weekend breaks.These aspirations are very much in keeping with the council’s Community Plan Single Outcome Agreement   in particular relating to National Policy Priorities i.e. economic recovery, growth and employment.We are also very much aware of organisations which have worked hard to promote the long-term outcomes in the Community Plan.The communities of Kintyre need a modern connectivity system, fit for purpose,this area is to have any credibility in the big wide world.Decent flight connections to the major hubs of Glasgow and Edinburgh would be a start.I have confirmed the Scottish Government is collecting views andyou would like to help improve our air service and have additional comments or suggestions, I urge you to email them to: Michael.Bratcher@transport. gov.scotAndrew Hemmings,

title: more options for senior students at cgs
story: Parents of young people at Campbeltown Grammar Schoolhad their say on proposals to give senior pupils the opportunity to study a wider choice of subjects.At an open information evening last week, head teacher David Fyfe updated parents on the progress the school has made since its HM inspection last year, and spoke about plans to increase the number of subjects currently on offer, as suggested by inspectors.In order to provide six subjects in the senior phase, the school is considering increasing the number of periods in the week to seven a day.Consultation with pupils and staff began in August last year, and Mr Fyfe emphasised how much the opinions of parents are valued in the process.The school is looking at a choice of two new timetable models: Monday to Friday with seven periods, giving  periods a week or three days a week with seven periods and two days a week with six, giving  periods a week.At the moment, there are  periods a week.In addition to the timetable change, S and S students will maximise their time in school instead of being able to #sign out#.Pupils will be encouraged to study additional subjects, assist junior students in class, and volunteer in the community to gain Saltire Awards.Special arrangements will still be possible to enable other wider achievements such as gaining a driving licence.Mr Fyfe said: #We want our young people to make the best use of their time at school and gain valuable experiences which will benefit them when they leave.#S and S pupils will soon be required to give their initial option choices to allow the school to judge demand for each subject, although these will not be final.Mr Fyfe also shared the results of a parents and partners survey on the school#s visions and values and #rights respecting schools# charter.He said: #So far we have had  responses but there is still time for you to let us hear your views.#We really value input from parents so it is vital that as many people as possible come forward and make their opinions known.#The survey showed that . per cent of parents felt that the school#s aims, outlined in last week#s Courier, either fully capture what is important to the school, or capture it well.The survey also found, however, that . per cent of those who responded felt that they had #not been involved at all# with the development of the school#s vision and values, while . per cent felt they had not been involved in the development of the new curriculum.#That is what these consultations are about,# Mr Fyfe said, #these figures can certainly be improved but title: pupils scottish tribute in honour of burns
story: The school was packed with visitors for an afternoon of entertainment and refreshments last Thursday in honour of Scotland#s national bard.Despite there being less than  children involved in the production, the school hall was packed.The pupils, ranging from pre-five to P, recited Burns poetry, performed songs and even put on a mini pantomime.George, in P, sported a tartan shirt as he carried the haggis into the room but later, after a change of clothes, was transformed into the bard himself to give an extensive and humorous immortal memory off by heart.Another stand-out performance came from P Ashley, who seemed destined for the stage during her performance of My Hoggie, while Taylor in P not only performed the address to the haggis with no prompts but also displayed her footwork in the sword dance.The afternoon culminated in a performance of The Three Wee Pigs, a Scottish twist on the classic The Three Little Pigs tale with the added edition of Wee Reid Ridin# Hood, also known as Little Red Riding Hood.After a demonstration, the youngsters invited their family, friends and members of the public to join them in dancing the Dashing White Sergeant.Everybody linked arms and sang Auld Lang Syne to bring the afternoon to a traditional close.

title: thought for the week february 1 2019
story: February  marks the midpoint of winter, half way between the shortest day and the spring equinox.For Christians it has a particularly special meaning as it was  days after the birth of Jesus and the day when, according to Jewish custom, his grateful parents took him to the temple to give thanks to God.We believe that Jesus is the light of the world who will guide us through our own dark times.Many customs have grown around Candlemas and one of the most interesting came from Scotland.In the olden days, Candlemas was the day when children brought candles to school so that the classrooms would have light on dull days.As time went on, gas lighting took over from candlelight and the children brought money to school with which the teacher was supposed to buy sweets for the children.The child who brought in the most money was declared Candlemas King or Queen and they ruled for six weeks.They had the power to make one whole afternoon a week a playtime and to excuse anyone they wished from any form of punishment.I don#t think this will catch on in Argyll!I think it is a lovely custom to take a child to church or temple for a blessing and to give thanks to God for their birth.I have the privilege of being chaplain to two primary schools and while I cannot take the children physically to church or temple, I take each one of them to God every day in my prayers to give thanks for them and ask God#s blessing upon them.

title: wee toon dancer is set for the stage
story: A Campbeltown woman who took her first steps into the world of dance with Footnotes Dance Company will perform in her first professional show at Glasgow Royal Concert Hall.Morgan Irwin, , who is in the final year of her BADance course at Performing Art Studio Scotland , will join three West End stars in the fth annual Movies to Musicals production on Friday February .Morgan will dance, act and sing in her role in the musical theatre cast, supporting stars Kerry Ellis, John Owen Jones and Lucy Kay in the Glasgow Philharmonia Orchestra production.After leaving Campbeltown Grammar School and Footnotes behind, Morgan moved to Glasgow where she gained NC, HNC and HND qualications, before moving to Edinburgh to study at PASS, one of the only places in Scotland to teach dance to degree level.She studies ballet, jazz and contemporary dance, as well as choreography, teaching and dance science.Despite never professionally singing, a friend convinced her to audition for the Movies to Musicals role.#I was apprehensive as I had to prepare a song as part of the audition,# Morgan said. #I have always just danced and done bits of acting but never singing, but I went along anyway and was successful.#When she s to Campbeltown, Morgan holds dance classes for nursery, primary and secondary school children.She said: #The classes aren’t one set style, I change it up every time. They’re mostly jazz funk where I do fun dance games, introduction to the basic technique of dance, as well as learning routines and basic gymnastics skills.#Morgan says that after she graduates in June, her #perfect scenario# would be to start a professional dance contract in September, somewhere like India or on a cruise ship, adding: #As long as I’m dancing or teaching dance I’ll be living my dream job!#Morgan Irwin will perform in the fth annual #Movies to Musicals#. Visitors also enjoyed coffee, soft drinks, cake and biscuits served by members of the parent council.ldquoThe open day gave dozens of people the opportunity to meet classmates they had not seen for numerous years.ldquoThey all thoroughly enjoyed catching up with each other and many iniduals took along their own photos of their memories at Wallyford over the decades.The open day was also supported by local councillors and keen photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, who caught the event on camera for posterity.Mr Hadden said: ldquoAll the organisers and those who contributed with memorabilia are to be congratulated for all their hard work, time and effort in bringing this event together.ldquoThanks also to everyone who came and supported this Wallyford Primary School open day, making it such a memorable, successful occasion before its doors close.Pauline Clark, parent council representative, said: ldquoWhat a day it was. title: tims-tales-through-the-keyhole
story: RECENTLY a friend and fellow storyteller with his family took me and my family on a simple but stunning walk along the shoreline of Dunbar. It was a cold day but my friend, who is skilled in bushcraft, had brought his portable fire pit with him.We searched for drtwood and sat by the fire, roasting marshmallows and warming our hands. It was a short walk but dramatic rock formations loomed above us, making it feel like a real adventure. The kids climbed them and explored the rocky beach, where once there had been an open-air bathing pool.On our , we went through a small tunnel-like arch. I stopped for a moment, suddenly taken by the view. The ruins of Dunbar Castle were beautully framed by the archway. Locals call this archway the keyhole and I reflected that the term is a perfect name.When we look through a keyhole, our vision is narrowly focussed. Such was the effect here. It cast a visual spotlight on what is left of what was once a mighty fortress.The kids trundled on before me, noticing smaller wonders: a frozen worm on the path, a sea shell and interesting-looking stones. But I stood for some moments, taking in the view beyond and thinking of what stories those old stones of the castle could tell.Many people pass this way every day, both locals and visitors. Itrsquos a section of the John Muir Way. I have often been with my family to Dunbar Leisure Pool and the harbour and town. But somehow I had missed this short but spectacular nearby walk until this day.Dunbar Castle is now but a fallen-down ruin. Indeed, itrsquos dficult to imagine what it once was. But the weathered sandstone castles on the shoreline built by nature still stand defiant, somehow reminding us of their greater permanence in the face of human transience. But as I stood looking at the ruins, the keyhole focussed my thoughts as well as my vision.History is also viewed through a keyhole, a very narrow one. The lives and events of the castle were lived in most part unrecorded by it. The spotlight of history has illuminated only brief moments, and even then the characters have been only those deemed lsquoimportantrsquo.There are moments where the view through the narrow keyhole of history has included insights to untold stories. The bravery of Black Agnes, as she defied the siege in , is one of those. With her husband away, she was in charge of this important fortress during war with England. She refused to give up the castle, even in the face of bombardment and attempts to starve her small garrison into submission. Her mocking of her besiegers by dusting down the battlements with her maids after a bombardment is an image seared in legend.But itrsquos a chink of light on a huge untold story we are led to believe by historyrsquos silence that women were insignicant players in events. For sure they were oppressed and put down by a system that centred on male power, but they are half of humanity and at least half the story.As the actions of Black Agnes reveal, even with such constraints put on them, women were there, part of events and often refusing to accept their assigned role.The le of Mary Queen of Scots has always been for me an example of this. Yes, she was privileged and powerful by birth, but because of this history took notice of her.Despite all the political and religious challenges she faced, it was her womanhood which men deemed her main failing. And so she was judged by dferent standards. Had she behaved with the morals of her father she would not have lasted five minutes in power. But no one raised an eyebrow because he was a man.But more than this, even though Mary was the monarch, her royal authority was deemed diluted and even less legitimate merely because she was a woman.So she understood she needed to find a husband to bring her royal authority to full strength in a country full of powerful and bullying misogynist men.She chose the dashing young Darnley, and the fact that he turned out to be dross was not, in my opinion, Maryrsquos fault. How easy it is to blame a woman for a manrsquos failings. She was taken in by him it was he who was the failure, not her.Thatrsquos what Irsquove always maintained, despite the protestations of my tutors at university. And her third husband Bothwell, well he was a disappointment as well.It is the stones of Dunbar,they could speak, who could tell us of the truth of his forced union with Mary. She had been taken there by him in April . The circumstances of this still remain debated. Was she abducted by him as later claimed, or did she go willingly It was also claimed she was raped and forced to marry Bothwell soon afterwards to save her honour . This idea has been disputed by some because Mary is said to have miscarried with twins while imprisoned at Lochleven Castle some months after, suggesting a relationship with Bothwell even before Darnleyrsquos murder. So a woman cannot be abused by a man she has had a relationship with  Really If they could talk, the stones of Dunbar would whisper the truths of those events in , and the despair and desperation of a strong and clever woman whose destiny was stolen mainly because of her sex.These were my thoughts as I stood looking through the keyhole towards Dunbar Castle. Suddenly, my daughter Manja broke my trance by wiggling the frozen worm in front of me. I smiled and thought to myself that thankfully times have changed since the days when the castle was a fortress.But sometimes, I fear, not as much as we think they have.

title: new-fidra-gin-hoping-for-east-lothian-base
story: Fidra Gin is the brainchild of Emma Bouglet and Jo Brydie and is currently based at Ballencrieff and Aviemore.The duo came together to create the juniper berry-based drink and have already enjoyed immediate success, with the product already available in a number of Edinburgh restaurants.Now they are hoping to make it  per cent based in the county, with plans under way to find suitable premises.Emma said: ldquoWe pick all the botanicals in East Lothian and, at the moment, we use a still in Aviemore.ldquoA friend has lent us his still for the time being so we can get enough momentum behind us and bring the whole operation to East Lothian.ldquoWe have potentially secured a premise in East Lothian. We are hoping to purchase a couple of stills so the whole operation is based in East Lothian.ldquoWe have had health and safety out and given it the go-ahead but there are a few bits and pieces to be sorted.The duo aim to have the new distillery open before the end of the year.Before Christmas, Emma and Jo, , were in the process of getting more than  bottles ready.Emma was delighted to say that had proven a great success, with the bottles selling out within a matter of hours after they were launched.Since then, more than  bottles have been produced and sold.Emma said their Scottish dry gin was ldquovery botanical and added: ldquoIt is quite a smooth gin, with a hint of sea buckthorn.The move into the gin business is something of a departure from their day jobs, with the duo aiming to make it their full-time business.Emma used to work as an investment banker before switching to becoming a childminder, while Jo runs her freelance podiatry from Longniddry, occasionally working in the local clinic, and before then she worked at Musselburgh Racecourse.Emma, , said: ldquoMe and Jo have known each other for years. Our kids are very good friends and my husband ndash who owns a wine company in Fe ndash knew Jo from her time at the racecourse.

title: well-known-late-haddington-resident-to-be-honoured-with-street-name
story: Vera Ingle ndash who passed away in  ndash was well-known in Haddington for her fundraising efforts for good causes.Now, East Lothian Council has confirmed that Vera Ingle Grove will make up part of the townrsquos new Letham Mains development.Her son Charles felt his mum was a very worthy choice.He said: ldquoWe are delighted, absolutely delighted.ldquoI had an indication it would be Vera Ingle Grove sometime ago and I know the idea was put forward by the community council, who have done a great job.ldquoThe response has been quite overwhelming and it has been lovely to see a lot of what has been said on social media.More than  new homes are being built on the townrsquos western edge as part of the development, which will also include a new primary school.Mr Ingle, a former Haddington councillor, said: ldquoThe reality is a lot of people knew my mother. She was a community person and that is quite important to a lot of people.ldquoSometimes we forget about community or scoff at it, but a lot of people still think it is important.ldquoShe to some extent exemplied the good qualities associated with that and the work she did within the town for local and national charities.Vera, who had six children,  grandchildren and four great-granddaughters, was most associated with raising funds for the poppy appeal.However, she also helped raise money for the day centre, Haddington Pipe Band, Red Cross and to fight multiple sclerosis among others.Previously, Mr Ingle said: ldquoThere is not a charity in the town, from the day centre to any other, that did not benefit from her.John Hamilton, treasurer of the community council, previously asked members of the public for key figures in Haddingtonrsquos history who could have streets named after them.He said: ldquoVera was one of lersquos endearing characters, known by many with her time in the Corn Exchange and her charity fundraising with her collection box out on the streets. Irsquom sure her family, friends and everyone  who knew her will be proud of this recognition.Ward councillor Tom Trotter was similarly pleased with the announcement.He said: ldquoIf we are going to be naming streets after people, real people who made a dference in the community, then she certainly did that on numerous occasions.ldquoShe was a bit of a character and it is fantastic that she will be recognised in this manner.ldquoI think it is only right we remember people from the past but also it is right to celebrate people that made a dference presently.Provost John McMillan added: ldquoMany people in Haddington will have fond memories of Vera and her extensive charity fundraising efforts and involvement in many of the townrsquos clubs and organisations.ldquoNaming new streets in recognition of former residents offers some continuity in the growing town and will hopefully inspire some of our newer residents to find out more of Haddingtonrsquos history and community le.

title: great-grandmother-who-ran-drem-post-office-pens-her-life-story
story: May Fairbairn, who was born in Orkney but went to school in Morham, decided to write the story of her le to ensure her great grandchildren knew all about her.The -year-old spent three months putting together Neeps, Horses and Parcels, which is available to buy at Kesleyrsquos bookshop, Haddington.She said: ldquoWhat inspired me was I had thought about doing it for about  years.ldquoI now have four great-grandchildren and I am .ldquoIt was to have something left for my great grandchildren.ldquoMy great grandmother ndash I would have loved to have known what she did. It has really taken off beyond what I ever thought it would.Mrs Fairbairnrsquos family are originally from Orkney however, they moved to the mainland when she was four with her father John Robson finding work in Midlothian and then moving to East Lothian.Despite her long time away from Orkney, Mrs Fairbairn, who ran the Post Office in Drem for more than  years, where she now stays, felt the islands and East Lothian were very much home.Away from the Post Office, she also taught at The Compass School in Haddington, and volunteered at the townrsquos Roodlands Hospital, as well as at Appin Equestrian Centre, near Drem, which is run by her daughter Anne.She said: ldquoI have a lot of self-belief in myself and a lot of determination, which I inherited from my father. I was just looking for the next opportunity.Already, the autobiography has proven popular with family members, including daughters Anne and Fiona.Throughout writing the book, May kept it a secret from her family but was pleased to say it had met with a positive reception.May added her family were ldquovery proud and said: ldquoThey have been very, very supportive and my grandson and everyone, they have all been behind me.ldquoThey thought it was a marvellous surprise to them all.However, it was after retiring from running the Post Office that May decided tolsquohomersquo and to visit Orkney.She said: ldquoWhen I go up there, I feel Orkney is home.ldquoThere is just something that tells me thatI had not been widowed, I would certainly be up running a bed and breakfast.

title: woman-left-shaken-after-being-flashed-at-by-three-youths-in-underpass
story: Police are appealing for witnesses following the incident at about .pm on the A underpass, near Meadowmill Sports Centre, which left the victim "very shaken".The woman was walking towards Prestonpans from the Tranent area when she came across a group of about  youths - both males and females - aged between  and  years old.As she continued to walk through the underpass, three youths approached her and exposedthemselves at her.The victim was uninjured and fled from the scene. Officers are now appealing for witnesses and anyone with information is asked to come forward.Inspector Kevin Sinclair from Dalkeith Police Station said: ldquoThis has been a frightening experience for the victim who was thankfully uninjured but understandably very shaken by the ordeal.ldquoThis sort of behaviour is completely unacceptable. I would ask anyone who witnessed the group of youths in this area last night, or the incident in the underpass, to come forward to help with our investigation.ldquoAnyone who may be able to identy those involved, or have any information to help us trace them, should call us as soon as possible.The first suspect is described as white, ft ins tall, about  years old, of medium build with blond hair that had curls at the front. He was wearing black tracksuit bottoms, trainers and a black hoodie.The second is described as a white male, of slim build, with dark brown hair and was wearing black jogging bottoms, a black scarf over his mouth and a black hoodiewith writing on the front, possibly lsquoNorth Face.rsquoThe third suspect is described as a white male, smaller and younger than the others involved, wearing grey jogging bottoms and a black hoodie.Anyone with information shouldcontact Police Scotland on , quoting incident number  of  January, or Crimestoppers anonymously on   .

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: musselburgh-swimming-pool-shut-all-evening-after-faecal-incident
story: A spokeswoman for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "Regrettably we had to close the pool at Musselburgh Sports Centre on Monday at short notice around .pm."This was following a faecal accident."In line with our protocols and health and safety requirements, the pool was closed in order to complete a full treatment cycle."We fully appreciate the frustration and disappointment this closure caused however we also know that patrons will understand and accept this approach is necessary in such circumstances."The spokeswoman said that the pool reopened at am today .A post from Musselburgh Amateur Swimming Club on Twitter said: "Session cancelled ndash tonights session is unfortunately not running today due to an issue at the pool. We apologise for the short notice but this is outwith our control. We look forward to seeing everyone on Wednesday."

title: tranent-teenager-recovering-well-after-horror-skiing-accident
story: An air ambulance brought Nicholas Guest back from Sion on Monday, with the teenager now in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Older sister Lizzy was delighted her brother was one step closer to being able to come home.She told the Courier: ldquoHe is a lot happier for being back in Scotland. There is a big change in his presentation.ldquoWe are all glad he is back and just along the road now instead of travelling hundreds of miles.Nicholas, , of Tranentrsquos Lawson Way, was placed in a coma following an accident while skiing in the resort of Saas-Fee, near the Italian border, earlier this month.The teenager bumped his head on the ground after going over a jump and underwent surgery, with doctors monitoring his condition.On Monday evening, he arrived back in Scotland and Lizzy, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoHe is improving little bits all the time.ldquoHe has progressed quite a lot in the last two weeks considering how severe his injuries were.ldquoHe is awake for longer and he speaks a little bit more. He still has issues with his mobility but has been referred onto eye specialists, speech and language, and physiotherapy. He struggles on focusing his eyes a bit.ldquoBeing back in Scotland has made a massive dference just in terms of his mental health.ldquoAs well as his physical health improving, we are trying to encourage him to do as much as he can and we are trying to stimulate him to the maximum and get him recovering quicker.Nicholas plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s and was visited by a group from the rugby team in the hospital.A GoFundMe page was set up by Lizzyrsquos fianceacute, Daniel Hunter, to help cover the costs of the family going to visit Nicholas in Switzerland.An initial goal of pound, was quickly surpassed, with more than pound, now collected as the community rallies round.Lizzy said: ldquoWe are pretty amazed.ldquoIrsquom shocked, to be honest obviously we changed the goal when we realised quite a lot of people had donated.ldquoWe thought maybe people would help cover the expenses and it has been incredible.ldquoThat was really helpful and Nicholas appreciates it as well.ldquoIt has been great ndash even people we donrsquot know, friends of friends, that want to help. We donrsquot even know who they are and we are just really grateful they want to help us.Nicholas, who is in S at Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, faces a y recovery and rehabilitation period. It remains unclear when he will be able tohome, although Lizzy said her brother wanted to be home within three months.She added: ldquoNow we are going to be focusing on being there for Nicholas.ldquoWe have got our daily lives and jobs to go to but as a family we are all within a reasonable distance.ldquoWe can co-ordinate ourselves to be there at dferent times so he has always got someone with him.Lizzy and Nicholasrsquo mum Marian added: ldquoA great thank you to all who have supported us over the last couple of weeks and those who continue to do so. Nicholas knows about the support and it has had a huge impact on his recovery and wersquore very grateful for this.ldquoI also want to express thanks to all who help and support our family.ldquoThanks to the excellent staff at the Swiss hospital, air ambulance team, and staff at the Western General.To help support Nicholas, go to gofundme support-for-nicolas

title: musselburgh-racecourse-abandons-cheltenham-trials-weekend
