title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Wednesday  Feb  : PM

title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. When the planning application is submitted, an opportunity will be given for representations to be made to the Planning Authority.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Wednesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Wednesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. For more details of these cookies and how to disable them, see our cookie policy.

title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Wednesday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Check your cold weather payment eligibility says Ross MP as temperature plummets
story: Local MP Ian Blackford sayspeople in the Ross, Skye and Lochaber constituency he serves should check eligibility with their nearest Job Centre Plus.This follows an alert of a triggering of the payment for postcode areas IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, IV, between the period    to   .Cold weather payments are made from the Social Fund to certain recipients of Income Support, income-based Jobseekerrsquos Allowance, income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Universal Credit or Pension Credit during periods of very cold weather.To ldquotrigger the payments, the average temperature at a specied weather station must be recorded as, or forecast to be, degC or below for seven consecutive days.The scheme runs from November  to March  each year.The payment is a fixed amount for each week of cold weather. For many years this was set at pound. a week but the LabourGovernment increased the rate to pound a week as a temporary measure for winters - and -. In , the Coalition Government made the pound rate permanent.Payments should be made automatically to those entitled to them there should be no need to make a claim.However concerns have previously been raised that payments can be missed and Mr Blackford believes it is important that people, who believe that they may be eligible follow this through, particularly as the cold weather bites.He said: ldquoWe have been experiencing quite a prolonged period of cold and wet weather in the Highlands and Islands. It is hugely important that anyone eligible for a cold weather payment receives it. story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. It confirmed fourth-quarter shareholder idend payments of . cents a share, up . per cent on a year earlier.John Moore, senior investment manager at Brewin Dolphin, said: “Despite a volatile oil price at the tail end of last year, BP more than doubled profits in  as it showed cost, capital, and operational discipline across its businesses.“The company is aware of the changing energy landscape and is active in responding to that by going through signicant internal changes, in addition to external moves such as its deal to purchase BHP Billiton’s shale gas assets.“ may well be a year of further oil price volatility and additional industry change however, BP has shown a great deal of resilience and an ability to adapt to a rapidly changing energy landscape, which leaves it well placed.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit has a silver lining but jobs are going overseas stuart murdoch
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Nearly every major financial services firm has set up new offices outside the UK because of Brexit, writes Stuart Murdoch.Regardless of where the Brexit process ends up,it even happens at all, the fact is that it has already had a material and probably irreversible impact on the financial services sector in Scotland.Major financial institutions never stand still, constantly reviewing and updating their strategies to react to changes in their customers needs, challenges from competitors and regulatory updates.Global businesses are used to dealing with geopolitical uncertainty, and adapting to it.That’s why despite the lack of detail around the Brexit withdrawal agreement, and no matter what the finalised deal looks like, many companies in Scotland’s financial services sector have already moved to prepare themselves for all eventualities.Nearly every major Scottish financial services institution has set up new offices outside the UK, or have relocated staff historically based in the UK to existing offices where: Standard Le and Aviva to Ireland RBS to Frankfurt and Scottish Widows to Luxembourg are just a few examples of redeployment. These moves are hugely intensive and provide a short-term boost for local workers and the economy. Such projects also develop the expertise and credibility of Scotland’s already impressive pool of financial services talent. : Nicola Sturgeon: Real and growing risk of no-deal BrexitHowever, that fact remains that much high-value work generated by exporting financial services to the EU is draining out of the Scottish economy permanently.On the other hand, there are new opportunities emerging as a direct result of the Brexit effect – for example firms are bringing some foreign operations back to Britain. Whilst the inward surge is not expected to match what is being lost, we are seeing a trend of UK and foreign firms relocating parts of their business to the UK to ensure they can continue to support their UK customer base. This includes many UK insurers who had previously set up offshore subsidiaries.The driver for larger UK firms moving operations to the EU is to satisfy their European customers, who are seeking assurances that there will be no disruption to their services in the event that no withdrawal deal is reached.However, some customers have raised concerns about whether they will get the same levels of consumer protection as offered in the UK – such as the protection of the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.We are advising a range of organisations, including a number of high-growth, financial technology businesses, who are planning their international growth strategy with Brexit in mind. We are seeing particularly high levels of activity in the payments industry. Many expanding fintech businesses in Scotland have an ambitious global outlook.: Brexit: Queen to be evacuated in event of no-deal, reports claimIt would be much simpler for them to grow abroadthe EU wasn’t to suddenly become a ‘foreign’ jurisdiction. On the other hand, many of these firms already have processes in place to manage a truly international business. For those companies, the potential barriers to exporting financial services to EU are relatively simple to plan for.International trade in financial services is particularly restricted by the requirement of firms to be authorised to undertake regulated activities. This is why Brexit is a serious issue for the financial sector to contend with. Currently we are part of a common regulatory regime, so any firm authorised to provide financial services in one EU member state can effectively get permission to conduct business in any other member state, using a mechanism known as ‘passporting’. When we are no longer in the EU, UK firms will lose their rights to passport their permissions to the EU. UK firms will be subject to the same restrictions as other firms from where across the globe.The UK will be eligible to apply for equivalence in a limited number of regulated activities, but this process is not automatic. It requires the approval of the European Commission, which could take considerable time and be subject to political obstacles. If an equivalence is approved for the UK, there would be a requirement to maintain close alignment to the EU financial services regulations. The Commission has the discretion to withdraw their approval at any time, which would provide little certainty for UK firms.On the flipside, any EU firm wanting to trade here will have to satisfy the UK’s own rules. Even though no deal has been agreed at the moment, the UK Government has thus far given assurances that regardless of what happens we’ll continue to give EU firms the opportunity to continue trading whilst applying for UK permissions up to March . They must noty the UK regulators in advance of Brexit to get the temporary permissions, but this gives more certainty to EU firms trading here than the other way around as it stands.If we are looking for positives where there are some short-term benefits of a weaker pound, which helps keep inward investment into the UK on the radar as an appealing prospect, but there is a bigger foreign exchange risk for the future should our economy and currency value begin to erge signicantly from mainland Europe.We have been helping our clients to review their businesses in order to better understand how Brexit will affect them. In some cases, depending on their set-up, it turns out after a thorough analysis that there are few specic risks.However, the process has been useful as a prompt to look at their operations in detail to see where there could get more general business efficiencies and opportunities. That may be the one silver lining to emerge from the Brexit process, whether there are any more remains to be seen.Stuart Murdoch is a solicitor advocate and partner at Burness Paull LLP©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
